Politikere vil gerne have en gr√∏n omstilling, men de form√•r ikke at f√• visionerne realiseret, med de andre rammebetingelser de i√∏vrigt har fastlagt. 
Personligt ser jeg at eneste mulighed er at s√¶tte turbo p√• den rentable del af den gr√∏nne omstilling f.eks landplacerede solvarme og solcelleanl√¶g, og s√• satse p√• at markedsreglerne blive reguleret s√• meget at nye teknologier hele tiden f√•r plads i markedet - eksempelvis det intelligente energisystem og energilagring. Et andet eksempel ligger der et potentiale i den lokale udbygning f.eks. gennem Energif√¶lleskaber. Men det kr√¶ver at politikerne √•bner op for alle veje frem mod en gr√∏n omstilling. Der er og bliver ikke en stor motorvej frem til en konfliktfri gr√∏n omstilling. Det er et vejnet vi har brug for. Eller et blodforsyningssystem, som kan holde en organisk gr√∏n krop levende..
column5:
it‚Äôs a silly human trait to say 'i told you so,' but i must say it: 'i told you so' üòâ
from the start, i‚Äôve been skeptical about the fundamental idea of the energy islands. why not use the offshore wind technology we already knew? because it required powerful transmission lines on land‚Äîand presto, we could avoid that with energy islands‚Äîor could we? the problem is that we actually needed, and still need, the much larger renewable energy capacity that the vision of the energy islands represented. but it‚Äôs difficult to align the vision with market prices for electricity‚Äîand where the alternative, land-based installations, should be located. and the politicians didn‚Äôt put two and two together when they presented the vision. they spent 20 years creating the free electricity market but didn‚Äôt connect market prices with how payment for the energy islands would take place. a major downside was that many land-based wind projects were stopped in the meantime because we were supposed to get energy from the energy islands!
the many visions for power-to-x (ptx) factories face the same challenges. not to mention the hydrogen pipeline from denmark to germany. these investments have a significant risk profile‚Äîand it‚Äôs incredibly difficult to get this expansion going without state support. oops, there‚Äôs the conflict again‚Äîstate support and free market prices‚Äîagain and again. politicians want a green transition, but they fail to realize the visions within the other frameworks they‚Äôve set up.
personally, i see that the only option is to put the pedal to the metal on the profitable part of the green transition, such as land-based solar heating and solar panel installations, and then bet on market rules being adjusted enough that new technologies continuously find their place in the market‚Äîfor example, the intelligent energy system and energy storage. another example is the potential in local expansion, such as through energy communities. but it requires politicians to open up all paths towards a green transition. there isn‚Äôt and won‚Äôt be a major highway to a conflict-free green transition. we need a network of roads. or a blood supply system that can keep an organic green body alive.

N√•r det kommer til at eksekvere p√• samme planer, kniber det imidlertid gevaldigt, men jeg bliver ikke det fjerneste overrasket over at "man" fortsat mener, at vi n√•r de opstillede m√•l til tiden. 

Man m√• antage, at de selv tror p√• det, men indtil videre er de storstilede planer om havvindm√∏ller sat p√• pause, og der bygge i det hele taget ingen vindm√∏ller i √∏jeblikket - og nu udskydes s√• de h√∏jt besungne energi√∏er.

Dagbladet Information har talt med minister Lars Aagaard om kritikken fra Kraka Economics' rapport om den katastrofale √∏konomi i Energi√∏ Bornholm-projektet. Til kritikken siger Aagaard blandt andet, at selvom projektet vil koste danske skatteydere milliarder, vil det ogs√• f√∏re til lavere str√∏mpriser for danskerne, hvorfor (m√• man forst√•) projektet kommer danskerne til gode. 

I Kraka Economics har vi unders√∏gt, hvem det s√• prim√¶rt kommer til gode, at elpriserne falder: 

üî∏ Over 50% af statens skatteindt√¶gter kommer fra indkomstskatter betalt af husholdningerne. Den n√¶stst√∏rste kilde er moms, som b√•de husholdninger og virksomheder betaler, og som udg√∏r cirka 20% af skatteindt√¶gterne. S√• n√•r staten bruger penge, er det prim√¶rt finansieret af husholdningerne.

üî∏ Ser man p√• elforbruget, st√•r virksomhederne for cirka 2/3 af Danmarks elforbrug. Det betyder, at n√•r politikerne og Lars Aagaard fremh√¶ver, at statsst√∏tte til Energi√∏ Bornholm vil s√¶nke elpriserne, vil det prim√¶rt gavne dansk erhvervsliv, is√¶r de mest energiintensive virksomheder.

Disse nuancer er n√¶rmest frav√¶rende i den offentlige debat og i Aagaards argumentation, hvor det ikke tydeligt fremg√•r, at statsst√∏ttet vedvarende energi omfordeler penge fra husholdningerne til virksomheder, is√¶r dem med stort energiforbrug som PtX-producenter.
column5: in kraka economics, we have investigated who primarily benefits from the falling electricity prices resulting from the government-funded energy island bornholm project. over 50% of the state's tax revenues come from income taxes paid by households, with the next largest source being vat, which both households and businesses pay, accounting for about 20% of tax revenues. therefore, it is primarily the households that finance government spending. however, considering electricity consumption, businesses account for approximately two-thirds of denmark's electricity use. this means that when politicians, including minister lars aagaard, emphasize that state support for the energy island bornholm will lower electricity prices, it will primarily benefit the danish business sector, especially the most energy-intensive companies.

üîã Det √∏konomiske fundament for Energi√∏ Bornholm er s√¶rdeles udfordret. 31,5 mia. kr. lyder regningen p√• for staten, hvis man sp√∏rger embedsm√¶ndene i Energistyrelsen, men ‚Äùkun‚Äù 17,6 mia. kr., hvis man sp√∏rger forligspartierne. For politikerne har nemlig lagt et loft for, hvor dyrt projektet m√• blive for danskerne.

Den d√•rlige √∏konomi har f√•et fortalerne til at skifte over til ikke-√∏konomiske argumenter som forsyningssikkerhed og store PtX-potentialer, men heller ikke disse holder vand. Det skriver Frederik L√¶ss√∏e Nielsen, senior√∏konom i Kraka Economics, om i GridTech i dag.

Vindm√∏llerne ved Bornholm bidrager kun begr√¶nset til dansk forsyningssikkerhed. Energistyrelsen har p√•peget, at ekstra vindm√∏ller i √òsters√∏en ikke v√¶sentligt √∏ger str√∏mproduktionen i perioder med lav produktion. Og selve udlandsforbindelsen til Tyskland, der faktisk bidrager til forsyningssikkerheden, kan med al sandsynlighed f√•s billigere.

Der er mange gode grunde til at √∏ge elmarkedsintegrationen mellem Nord- og Sydeuropa, men det skal selvf√∏lgelig g√∏res ordentligt og ikke bare fungere som undskyldning for at forts√¶tte med et √∏konomisk katastrofalt projekt, hvor den del af projektet, der faktisk kan retf√¶rdigg√∏res, kunne f√•s billigere.

Desuden er Bornholm ikke oplagt til produktion af brint og andre PtX-produkter p√• grund af h√∏je omkostninger. En rapport fra DTU, der sammenligner produktionsomkostninger p√• Bornholm med omkostningerne i Vesteuropa, USA og Kina, viser nemlig, at det vil v√¶re dyrest at producere brint og at viderefor√¶dle det til ammoniak, hvis man g√∏r det p√• Bornholm. Det betyder, at PtX-produktion p√• Bornholm n√¶ppe bliver konkurrencedygtigt m√•lt p√• pris.

Vi mangler stadig at h√∏re √©t eneste godt argument for at etablere den milliarddyre Energi√∏ Bornholm.
column5:
i want to stress that the economic foundation for energi√∏ bornholm is highly challenged. the state's estimated cost is 31.5 billion dkk, according to civil servants in the danish energy agency, while the agreement parties estimate it at only 17.6 billion dkk, as politicians have set a cap on how expensive the project can be for danes.

due to the poor economy, advocates have shifted to non-economic arguments such as energy security and large ptx potentials, but these do not hold up either. wind turbines at bornholm contribute only limitedly to danish energy security. the danish energy agency has pointed out that additional wind turbines in the baltic sea do not significantly increase electricity production during periods of low production. moreover, the international connection to germany, which actually contributes to energy security, could likely be obtained more cheaply.

there are many good reasons to increase electricity market integration between northern and southern europe, but it should be done properly and not just used as an excuse to continue with an economically disastrous project where the part of the project that can be justified could be obtained more cheaply.

furthermore, bornholm is not suitable for producing hydrogen and other ptx products due to high costs. a report from dtu, which compares production costs on bornholm with those in western europe, the usa, and china, shows that it would be most expensive to produce hydrogen and further process it into ammonia on bornholm. this means that ptx production on bornholm is unlikely to be competitive in terms of price.

we still have not heard a single good argument for establishing the billion-dollar energi√∏ bornholm.
column13: Are there more cost-effective ways to reach the emissions targets?

column3:
‚ÄùHvis ikke det kan dokumenteres, at projektet giver samfunds√∏konomisk overskud, b√∏r det droppes.‚Äù 

S√•dan skrev De √∏konomiske vism√¶nd om Energi√∏ Bornholm i deres efter√•rsrapport 2024. I samme omb√¶ring anbefalede de, at man medtager flere effekter i den samfunds√∏konomisk vurdering, bl.a. forsyningssikkerhed.

Vi har derfor fors√∏gt at sandsynligg√∏re, om gevinsterne ved √∏get forsyningssikkerhed er nok til at forsvare projektets skrantende √∏konomi. Til det er svaret nej. 

Det skyldes grundl√¶ggende:
‚óæ Projektet har et samfunds√∏konomisk underskud p√• 7 mia. kr., mens et forsigtigt bud p√• projektets forbedring af forsyningssikkerheden har en v√¶rdi p√• cirka 3 mia. kr.
‚óæ En analyse fra Energinet viser f√¶rre problemer med effekttilstr√¶kkeligheden (om der er str√∏m nok) fremadrettet, end tidligere antaget.
‚óæ Det er prim√¶rt udlandskablet til Tyskland, der bidrager til forsyningssikkerheden. Det er dog sv√¶rt at forestille sig, at det ikke kunne f√•s billigere end via en omvej over Bornholm.
‚óæ Klimar√•det har tidligere p√•peget, at udlandsforbindelser ikke er den mest effektive m√•de at √∏ge forsyningssikkerheden, da solen skinner, og vinden bl√¶ser p√• nogenlunde samme tid i vores nabolande. Der er derfor stor sandsynlighed for, at de vil mangle str√∏m p√• samme tidspunkter.

Selv hvis nye samfunds√∏konomiske beregninger mod forventning viser positiv samfunds√∏konomi, b√∏r man som altid sammenligne med alternativer, der l√∏ser samme opgave. Her er det ikke vores vurdering, at Energi√∏ Bornholm er det projekt, der l√∏ser opgaven bedst.

Vi vurderer derfor, at √∏get forsyningssikkerhed n√¶ppe er tilstr√¶kkeligt til at forsvare energi√∏en. N√•r det er sagt, er det en god ide at f√• emnet gennemanalyseret af Energistyrelsen. Der er dog ikke lang tid til, at Energinet skal underskrive kontrakter p√• infrastruktur fx elkablet mellem Sj√¶lland og Bornholm, og derfor er det vigtigt, at man s√¶tter hele projektet p√• pause, indtil analyserne er f√¶rdige. Det bliver nemlig markant dyrere at droppe projektet, hvis man f√∏rst har indg√•et kontrakter p√• dyr infrastruktur.
column5:
"if it cannot be documented that the project provides a socio-economic surplus, it should be dropped."

this is what the economic council wrote about energy island bornholm in their autumn report 2024. at the same time, they recommended including more effects in the socio-economic assessment, such as supply security.

we have therefore tried to determine whether the benefits of increased supply security are enough to justify the project's struggling economy. the answer is no.

this is fundamentally due to: 
‚óæ the project has a socio-economic deficit of 7 billion dkk, while a cautious estimate of the project's improvement in supply security is valued at approximately 3 billion dkk. 
‚óæ an analysis from energinet shows fewer problems with capacity adequacy (whether there is enough power) going forward than previously assumed. 
‚óæ it is primarily the foreign cable to germany that contributes to supply security. however, it is hard to imagine that this could not be obtained cheaper than via a detour over bornholm. 
‚óæ the climate council has previously pointed out that foreign connections are not the most effective way to increase supply security, as the sun shines and the wind blows at roughly the same time in our neighboring countries. therefore, there is a high probability that they will lack power at the same times.

even if new socio-economic calculations unexpectedly show a positive socio-economic outcome, alternatives that solve the same task should always be compared. here, it is not our assessment that energy island bornholm is the project that solves the task best.

we therefore assess that increased supply security is unlikely to be sufficient to justify the energy island. that said, it is a good idea to have the topic thoroughly analyzed by the danish energy agency. however, there is not much time before energinet has to sign contracts on infrastructure, such as the power cable between zealand and bornholm, and therefore it is important to put the entire project on hold until the analyses are completed. it will be significantly more expensive to drop the project if contracts on expensive infrastructure have already been signed.
column13: Do we have the right assessment criteria to evaluate if energy islands are a good idea?

column3:
Energi√∏ Bornholm blev oprindeligt vedtaget under foruds√¶tning af rentabilitet ‚Äì alts√• som minimum hvile √∏konomisk i sig selv eller give indtjening til staten. Sidenhen har analyser fra Energistyrelsen vist et forventet st√∏ttebehov p√• hele 31,5 mia. kr., hvoraf det politisk er besluttet, at man h√∏jst vil betale 17,6 mia. kr. Men trods det store underskud bliver der ufortr√∏dent arbejdet videre med projektet.

Denne insisteren p√• at forts√¶tte med et √∏konomisk katastrofalt projekt virker endnu mere underlig, n√•r man tager h√∏jde for, at projektet prim√¶rt bidrager med √∏get eksport til udlandet. Allerede i 2030 forventes elproduktionen at overstige det indenlandske forbrug, hvis man ser bort fra PtX-produktion. Dette sp√¶nd mellem Danmarks str√∏mproduktion og det indenlandske elforbrug forventes derudover at stige st√∏t frem til 2050.

Energi√∏ Bornholm bidrager s√•ledes hovedsageligt til √∏get eksport, og som vist p√• figuren forventes Danmark at v√¶re nettoselvforsynende fra 2030 og frem b√•de med og uden Energi√∏ Bornholm. Det betyder, at hvis projektet gennemf√∏res, ender danskerne med at betale adskillige milliarder for et projekt, der prim√¶rt bidrager med billigere str√∏m og PtX-produkter til vores rige nabolande.

‚úã Dette er blot et af de mange argumenter, der er for at droppe Energi√∏ Bornholm. L√¶s mere i vores rapport ‚ÄùEnergi√∏ Bornholm ‚Äì En √∏konomisk katastrofe i slowmotion‚Äù - du finder et link til rapporten i kommentarfeltet.
column5:
energy island bornholm was originally approved on the condition of profitability ‚Äì that is, at a minimum, to be economically self-sustaining or generate revenue for the state. subsequently, analyses from the danish energy agency have shown an expected need for support of a whopping 31.5 billion dkk, of which it has been politically decided that a maximum of 17.6 billion dkk will be paid. but despite the large deficit, work on the project continues unabated.

this insistence on continuing with an economically disastrous project seems even more peculiar when considering that the project primarily contributes to increased exports abroad. already by 2030, electricity production is expected to exceed domestic consumption, excluding ptx production. this gap between denmark's electricity production and domestic consumption is expected to steadily increase until 2050.

thus, energy island bornholm mainly contributes to increased exports, and as shown in the figure, denmark is expected to be net self-sufficient from 2030 onwards, both with and without energy island bornholm. this means that if the project is carried out, danes will end up paying several billion for a project that primarily provides cheaper electricity and ptx products to our wealthy neighboring countries.

‚úã this is just one of the many arguments for dropping energy island bornholm. read more in our report "energy island bornholm ‚Äì an economic catastrophe in slow motion" - you can find a link to the report in the comment section.
column13: Who benefits socially and economically from energy islands? Is it fair?

column3:
Besides #Megaton, Denmark is also involved in the energy islands #Vind√ò (https://lnkd.in/eyxEBjjA) and #Brint√∏ (https://lnkd.in/eC_JG-en). While these projects are remarkable in the European context.

However, the Scandinavian countries are definitely pioneers and, along with Portugal's 1GW-H2 (https://lnkd.in/ef_itJxN), form the #HydrogenBeacon of Europe."

column3:
Energi√∏en p√• 3.000 MW skal v√¶re afs√¶t for udvikling p√• klippe√∏en, mener borgmester Jacob Tr√∏st. Hans √∏nskeliste r√¶kker fra en klimaerhvervsskole til PtX-produktion. Samtidig er borgerinitiativet Bornholms Havvind i gang med at tegne andel til en kystm√∏llepark p√• 100 MW, der kan st√• klar i 2026

Bem√¶rkningen var generel, men den samme tanke har de p√• klippe√∏en, som l√¶gger jord til energi√∏ens transformerstation p√• op mod 90 hektar for en havm√∏llevindpark p√• mellem 3 og 3,8 GW.

Det anl√¶g omfattes ikke af VE-loven kompensation (gr√∏n pulje) til lokalsamfund, som g√¶lder land- og kystn√¶re vindm√∏ller samt solceller. Bornholms konservative borgmester, Jacob Tr√∏st (K), opfordrer regering og folketing til en lov√¶ndring, der omfatter store landanl√¶g. 

-Det er rimeligt med en eller anden form for kompensation til det lokalsamfund, der l√¶gger jord til anl√¶g af den st√∏rrelse, sagde turist- og natur√∏ens borgmester p√• et pressem√∏de med FEM - Foreningen af Energi- og Milj√∏journalister den 9. marts.

PtX deler vandene politisk. Nogle er t√∏vende, og nogle siger fuld fart frem. Personligt kan jeg se et stort potentiale i PtX-produktion. Det kunne give os nye muligheder i forhold til fjernvarme og spildevand, flere arbejdspladser og afledte erhverv - landbruget kunne m√•ske udvikle nye produktionsmetoder med varmt vand, siger Jacob Tr√∏st.

Her er han inspireret af Greenlab Skive, som tiltr√¶kker virksomheder, der kan flytte ind med kort varsel, fordi det gr√∏nne erhvervsomr√•de er forberedt. 

-Det politiske flertal siger, at vi vil gerne have flere arbejdspladser til Bornholm for at f√• forretningen Bornholm til at k√∏re rundt. Vi har brug for et bedre skattegrundlag og flere borgere, siger Jacob Tr√∏st.
column5:
the 3,000 mw energy island project should serve as a foundation for development on bornholm. my vision includes initiatives such as a climate vocational school and ptx (power-to-x) production facilities. additionally, the local citizen initiative, bornholms havvind, is working on a 100 mw coastal wind farm that could be operational by 2026.

bornholm will host a transformer station of up to 90 hectares for an offshore wind farm generating between 3 and 3.8 gw. however, this facility does not qualify for community compensation under the danish renewable energy act, which currently covers only land-based and coastal wind turbines and solar panels. i urge the government and parliament to amend the law to include large land-based installations, as it is fair for the local community hosting such a large facility to receive some form of compensation.

i see significant potential in ptx production, despite political divisions on the matter. ptx could create new opportunities for district heating, wastewater management, job creation, and related industries. for example, agriculture could innovate using hot water from ptx processes. greenlab skive serves as an inspiration, demonstrating how a prepared green business area can attract companies ready to establish operations quickly.

bornholm needs more jobs, an improved tax base, and a growing population to sustain its economy. the majority of political leaders support creating more jobs on the island to ensure bornholm‚Äôs long-term economic viability.

column3:
üå¨Ô∏è Exciting Times Ahead for US Offshore Wind! üåä 
 
As highlighted in the latest 2024 US Offshore Wind Market Report published by Liz Burdock and our great team from Oceantic Network, the #US market is on the cusp of significant growth and development in the coming months. With the market largely stabilizing and returning to growth, there's immense potential for supply chain advancements, increased investment, and a resurgence in shipbuilding activity. 
 
According to the report, in 2024 US states could award up to 1550 MW of new power offtake, with a substantial portion aimed at replenishing lost contracts. Additionally, the forecast indicates a continued rise in approved construction capacity, reaching at least 14.6 GW this year. 
 
Despite facing setbacks, 2023 witnessed pivotal announcements regarding new manufacturing facilities, port infrastructure upgrades, and the introduction of offshore wind vessels. Moreover, states have been diligently working on fostering interstate cooperation frameworks to stabilize regional markets, reduce project costs, and enhance economic benefits. 
 
During my recent visit to the US last week, I was encouraged by the strong commitment from clients and partners to reignite the offshore wind sector. Engaging discussions were held on strategies to overcome challenges and capitalize on opportunities for growth.  
 
While the enthusiasm is high, it's crucial to acknowledge the upcoming uncertainty in the US market in 2024. With the Federal election on the horizon, there's a growing societal critique of offshore wind's impact on electricity bills and concerns about meeting promises on local job creation. 
 
As a member of the Board of Directors for Oceantic Network and with the support of my dedicated team at Ramboll, I am deeply committed to driving the success of US offshore wind. Together, we endeavour to advocate for a more balanced market design and regulatory framework that aligns with broader societal interests, paving the way for a sustainable future. 
 
Let's harness this momentum, address challenges head-on, and collectively contribute to a thriving and sustainable US offshore wind industry! üí®üåé #USOffshoreWind #DecarbonizingForNetZero #PartnerForSustainableChange

This week the Oceantic team published our 2024 U.S. Offshore Wind Market Report, and I‚Äôm so excited to share it with you. It‚Äôs packed with valuable info you need to stay informed about our rapidly evolving industry, from market trends and supply chain advancements to policy changes over the past year. 
 
This comprehensive report is more than just a collection of data, it‚Äôs a strategic guide that delves into the future of the industry, making predictions for 2024 that could shape the course of offshore wind development in the U.S., including: 
  
-Potential for 3+ new lease auctions as the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management (BOEM) opens new areas in the Gulf of Maine, Central Atlantic, Oregon Coast, and the Gulf of Mexico.  
-With the U.S. market largely stabilizing and returning to growth mode, the next twelve months have the potential to bring significant supply chain development, further investment, and renewed shipbuilding activity.  
-By December, states could award as much as 15.5 GW of new power offtake, approximately 60% of which will be used to replenish lost contracts.  
-The total capacity approved for construction will continue rising to at least 14.6 GW  
 
If you‚Äôre curious to dive deeper into these insights, you can download the executive summary for free. This is your trick to staying ahead of the curve offshore wind friends!

This panel explores the essential components for developing a scalable, financially durable supply chain and identifying advancements in offshore wind technology to develop a sustainable industry and enable on-time construction and reliable project operations in California and beyond.

The islands are developed by Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners and will create +10.000 jobs during construction, many of them in local German coastal communities. 

They will significantly reduce the costs of renewable energy and hydrogen - exactly what we need now to further drive the energy transition, boost economic growth, and gain more social acceptance for this needed transition.

Not least, these islands will allow the German offshore wind industry, who plans offshore wind farms +150km from shore, to rescue our colleagues in case of an emergency out at sea

I fredags i sidste uge lancerede Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners et nyt energi√∏selskab, Copenhagen Energy Islands, der skal udvikle energi√∏er i Nords√∏en, √òsters√∏en og Syd√∏stasien
 
I mandags i denne uge blev der indg√•et et nyt energi√∏samarbejde mellem Bornholm, √Öland og Gotland.
 
Det tyder alts√• p√•, at energi√∏erne s√• sm√•t tager fodf√¶ste efter de seneste m√•neders tvivl om energi√∏ernes status.
 
Det har f√•et mig og gode samarbejdspartnere i vindindustrien til at pege p√• tre vigtige budskaber, hvad ang√•r fremtidige energi√∏er.
 
For det f√∏rste kan den gr√∏nne omstilling kun lykkes, hvis vi etablerer energi√∏er p√• havet, hvor energien samles og fordeles til de omkringliggende lande.
 
For det andet er vi n√∏dt til at erkende, at en infrastruktur med energi√∏er p√• havet er et teknologisk nybrud.
 
For det tredje kan ovenst√•ende kun ske, hvis vi g√•r sammen i forpligtende og langsigtede partnerskaber.
 
Skal vi etablere en dansk styrkeposition inden for n√¶ste generation af offshore vindenergi, s√• kommer vi ikke uden om energi√∏erne!
column5:
the recent launch of copenhagen infrastructure partners' new energy island company, copenhagen energy islands, and the new energy island collaboration between bornholm, √•land, and gotland indicate that energy islands are gradually gaining momentum despite recent doubts about their status.

there are three critical messages regarding future energy islands. first, the green transition can only succeed if we establish energy islands at sea, where energy is collected and distributed to surrounding countries. second, we must acknowledge that building an infrastructure with offshore energy islands represents a technological breakthrough. third, achieving this requires committed and long-term partnerships.

if denmark wants to establish a leading position in the next generation of offshore wind energy, energy islands are indispensable.
column13: Are energy islands a good investment for innovation and economic growth?

column3:
Sp√¶ndende emne og debat der rejses mht Energi√∏erne. 
Som akt√∏r i den gr√∏nne omstilling, st√∏tter Anori A/S, at kompentente fagfolk virkelig f√•r regnet p√• tingene, s√• myter ikke opst√•r og s√• modstanderne af den gr√∏nne omstilling ikke kan lave Fake News p√• noget s√• vigtigt.
N√•r vi taler energi√∏er, s√• vil vi fra Anori A/S gerne rette opm√¶rksomheden p√• den st√∏rste energi√∏ af dem alle - nemlig Gr√∏nland. 
Gr√∏nland har masser af plads, masser af vindpotentiale og muligheden for k√¶mpe store anl√¶g p√• land, til en pris der h√¶nger sammen.
Vi har et projekt p√• 1,5 GW landvind undervejs, der skal omdanne kold og tung arktisk vind til gr√∏n ammoniak. S√• tingene KAN godt lade sig g√∏re. S√• mangler man gr√∏nne projekter at investere i, s√• kan man kigge ud over hele Rigsf√¶llesskabet og ikke "kun" indenfor lille Danmark.
column5:
the debate surrounding energy islands is an exciting topic, and anori a/s, as a player in the green transition, supports ensuring that competent professionals thoroughly assess the situation. this will help prevent myths and allow opponents of the green transition from spreading fake news about something so crucial.

regarding energy islands, anori a/s wants to draw attention to the largest energy island of them all ‚Äì greenland. greenland offers vast space, immense wind potential, and the opportunity for large-scale land-based installations at a feasible cost. anori a/s is currently working on a 1.5 gw onshore wind project that will convert cold, heavy arctic wind into green ammonia. this proves that such projects are achievable. if investors are looking for green projects, they should look beyond just denmark and consider the entire kingdom of denmark, which includes greenland.
column13: Do we have the right assessment criteria to evaluate if energy islands are a good idea?

column3:
Next week on Thursday 25th, I am honored to provide a Thought-Leadership presentation at #IPF in New Orleans, the US premier offshore wind energy network event, organized by my fantastic colleagues from the Oceantic Network.

The recent challenges and delays in offshore wind contracting have demonstrated the fragility of the current approach to structuring energy offtake. Reaching this inflection point has reinforced the need to reconsider traditional market designs, especially as new solicitations draw nearer. I will therefore focus in my presentation on the potential to balance #sustainability metrics and social concerns with traditional financial measures, using a sample case of a Mid-Atlantic project. 

I hope attendees will leave with an understanding of current market designs, global benchmarks, novel ways to incorporate sustainability, and the challenges that remain to be solved. And obviously, I look very much forward to reflections and feedback on the topic, as we need all hands on deck to push the topic sustainability more into novel market designs across the offshore wind sector.
 
Hope to see you next week in New Orleans. If you have not yet signed up for it, here you go: https://lnkd.in/eDmnWuks

Hvorfor er industriklynger vigtige for den gr√∏nne omstilling og hvad har det med energi√∏er at g√∏re? 

I g√•r deltog vores CEO, Christopher Sorensen i en paneldebat om "Energi√∏er p√• land" arrangeret af Biogas Danmark. 

Tak for en sp√¶ndende diskussion til Daniel Ulf Pedersen og Bertel Maigaard om hvordan fremtidens energi√∏er skal se ud, hvorfor de skal v√¶re p√• land og hvilke investeringer, det vil kr√¶ve. 

I GreenLab er vores m√•l bl.a. at reducere behovet for investeringer i elnettet ved at placere produktionen af vedvarende energi t√¶t p√• de industrier, der har brug for energien. Virksomhederne i GreenLab kan dermed aftage str√∏mmen direkte og anvende den i deres produktion.

Samtidig kan str√∏m omdannes til varme (vand/damp), som kan bruges til i industriproduktion, ligesom overskudsvarme fra virksomhederne kan cirkuleres i et internt ‚Äùfjernvarmenet‚Äù inden for industriparken.
column5:
industrial clusters are crucial for the green transition, and they are closely connected to the concept of energy islands. yesterday, our ceo, christopher sorensen, participated in a panel discussion on "energy islands on land," organized by biogas denmark. thank you to daniel ulf pedersen and bertel maigaard for the engaging discussion about the future of energy islands, why they should be on land, and the investments required.

at greenlab, our goal is to reduce the need for investments in the electricity grid by locating renewable energy production near industries that need the energy. companies within greenlab can directly consume the energy in their production processes. additionally, electricity can be converted into heat (water/steam), which can be used in industrial production, and surplus heat from businesses can be recycled through an internal "district heating network" within the industrial park.
column13: Power-to-X and energy storage

Din elregning stiger snart kraftigt, mens prisen p√• str√∏m ofte er negativ. Hvad sker der? Energi√∏erne er igen p√• spil.. ü´£

Du og jeg kommer til at betale 10mia ekstra de n√¶ste 3 √•r til de kritiserede energi√∏er, gemt i tarifferne. Energi√∏er som m√•ske ikke sker. 

Din elregning best√•r for en lille del af prisen p√• str√∏mmen. Resten er elafgift og tariffer. Vi burde fjerne elafgiften, da den hindrer gr√∏n omstilling, men det vil de r√∏de partier ikke. En stor statskasse er vigtigere end klimaet synes de. 

Den anden store del er tariffer. Dem annoncerede Energinet forleden skal stige. Vi ved instinktivt godt at vores elektrificering kr√¶ver store nye investeringer i elnettet. Det er godt og fair at brugerne betaler for udvidelserne. Men jeg dykkede alligevel ned i det. I deres rapport p√• side 15 kan man se at den st√∏rste klump af hvad tarifferne g√•r til er "energi√∏er". Alts√• det socialdemokratiske luftkastel i Nords√∏en og det st√¶rkt kritiserede projekt p√• Bornholm, som prim√¶rt skal fodre Tyskland med str√∏m fordi de lukker deres egen produktion ned. 

Vi har sagt klart at den nuv√¶rende aftale hvor indt√¶gterne fra havvind kan bruges til at finansiere energi√∏bornholm er fin i et kompromis. Men vi g√•r ikke med til at afs√¶tte flere penge. Hvis enten E√òB bliver dyrere eller havvind tjener mindre. Nu viser det sig at du alligevel betaler mere for det hall√∏j. Godt gemt i tarifstigninger. Jeg gl√¶der mig meget til nye tal fra ministeriet omkring alt det her. Mere og mere tyder p√• at danskerne kunne spare mange penge p√• ikke at skulle fodre tyskerne med str√∏m lavet ved Bornholm.
column5:
your electricity bill is about to increase significantly, even though electricity prices are often negative. what is happening? the energy islands are once again at the center of the issue.

you and i will end up paying an extra 10 billion danish kroner over the next three years for the criticized energy islands, hidden in tariffs. energy islands that might never even materialize.

your electricity bill consists of a small portion for the price of electricity, but most of it is made up of electricity taxes and tariffs. the electricity tax should be removed, as it hinders the green transition, but the red political parties refuse to do so. it seems that a large state treasury is more important to them than climate concerns.

the other significant part is tariffs. energinet recently announced that tariffs will increase. we instinctively understand that electrification requires large new investments in the electricity grid, and it is fair for users to pay for these expansions. however, when i looked deeper into the matter, i found that, according to energinet's report, the largest portion of what the tariffs go toward is "energy islands." this refers to the social democratic fantasy project in the north sea and the highly criticized project on bornholm, which is primarily intended to supply germany with electricity as they close down their own production.

we have made it clear that the current agreement, where offshore wind revenues can be used to finance the bornholm energy island, is acceptable as a compromise. but we will not agree to allocate more funds. if either the energy island becomes more expensive or offshore wind earns less, we will not support further financial commitment. now, it turns out that you are still paying more for this, hidden in tariff increases. i look forward to receiving new figures from the ministry on this matter. more and more, it seems that the danish people could save a lot of money by not having to feed germany with electricity produced near bornholm.
column13: How to finance the energy islands?

"Nu p√•begynder vi Mars-rejsen. 
Energinet og 50Hertz p√•begynder nu i hast udbudsprocessen for dele af el-infrastrukturen til Energi√∏ Bornholm.
Det er tankev√¶kkende, at det kun er dele af anl√¶ggene, der udbydes. Dele af de meget vigtige HVDC-anl√¶g til konvertering (veksel/j√¶vn-str√∏m) ser ikke ud til at v√¶re indeholdt, men udskydes til senere! Man kan frygte, at det er, fordi man endnu ikke pr√¶cis ved, hvad det er, der skal indk√∏bes (begrundelsen synes at v√¶re hensyn til leverand√∏rerne). I InterOpera-projektet under EU arbejdes der med at beskrive standarder herfor og dette arbejde er ikke f√¶rdigt f√∏r om flere √•r! 
N√•r man l√¶ser Energinet's eget opslag anf√∏rt neden for og kigger p√• det meget kortfattede notat, med businessmodellen (for el-delen), s√• fremg√•r det, at netop HVDC-anl√¶gget udg√∏r en v√¶sentlig risiko:
Ny teknologi: Standarder for sammenkobling af HVDC-anl√¶g er endnu ikke udviklet, hvilket kan risikere at √∏ge prisen og leveringstiden p√• Energinets anl√¶g.

Synes derfor der er grund til en ikke ubetydelig bekymring for projektets rentabilitet og tidsforl√∏b. Det fremg√•r, at Energinets nettoudgifter til transmission overv√¶ltes p√• vindm√∏lleparkerne. Ogs√• et lidt uklart indhold. Hvilke konsekvenser er der mon for elforbrugerne?  

I grunden synes jeg, at en r√¶kke √∏konomiske og juridiske forhold vedr. denne energi√∏ (og ogs√• vedr. Energi√∏erne i Nords√∏en) er meget ringe belyst i offentligheden. I Norge har NVE udarbejdet 2 store rapporter om ""Regulering av nett til havs"". Hvorfor laves der dog ikke noget tilsvarende i Danmark, hvor tingene kan blive belyst og diskuteret inden politikerne - p√• et i mine √∏jne indtil nu meget rudiment√¶rt grundlag - skal tage stilling til mia-store investeringer? Som det blev sagt p√• en konference om Energyhubs i Dansk Industri af en repr√¶sentant fra DTU for nogle dage siden: Energi√∏erne er som en rejse til Mars!"
column5:
the danish ‚Äúenergy island‚Äù projects, particularly energi√∏ bornholm, are being advanced hastily without adequate preparation or transparency. energinet and 50hertz have begun the tender process for part of the electricity infrastructure, but critical components, such as the hvdc plant for alternating/direct current conversion, are excluded and delayed. this delay appears to result from uncertainty about what needs to be purchased, potentially to accommodate suppliers. the eu‚Äôs interopera project is working on defining standards for hvdc plants, but this process will not be completed for several years.  

energinet‚Äôs own documents highlight that the hvdc plant introduces risks due to its reliance on new and undeveloped standards, which could increase costs and delivery delays. additionally, energinet is passing transmission expenses to wind turbine parks, but the effects on electricity consumers remain unclear. denmark has not conducted or published comprehensive analyses on the economic and legal aspects of these energy islands, unlike norway, which has issued major reports on offshore grid regulation.  

the lack of publicly available information and thorough analysis means that politicians are making decisions on large investments based on an insufficient foundation. this is deeply concerning, as the profitability, timeline, and consumer impact of these projects remain uncertain. as a representative from dtu recently stated, these energy islands are akin to a journey to mars‚Äîhighly ambitious but fraught with significant challenges and risks.
column13: Do we have the right assessment criteria to evaluate if energy islands are a good idea?

column5:
sweden's decision to avoid cooperation on offshore wind power connections with denmark and germany raises significant questions about its impact on sweden's energy future and electricity prices. a potential plan b for offshore wind power outside southern sweden's territorial waters could involve obtaining permits in swedish waters while connecting the power to energy islands shared by denmark and germany. this approach aligns with ongoing collaboration between denmark, germany, and 50hertz, which has persisted since sweden withdrew from negotiations years ago.  

the lack of swedish involvement in this cooperative effort could lead to higher electricity prices and missed opportunities for shared infrastructure. the reasons behind sweden's withdrawal from these discussions remain unclear, but this decision may have long-term consequences for sweden's energy strategy and its ability to integrate into the broader regional energy network.

column3:
"Wind turbines don't *replace* fossil fuels. They *displace* them whilst they're working, which isn't all the time. 

During periods of calm weather ‚Äî common during the British winter ‚Äî wind generation plummets. In the absence of always-on nuclear and hydro, that means falling back on gas. We're in a situation where our carbon emissions are subject to the whims of the weather. 

This problem won't be solved ‚Äî indeed, can't be solved ‚Äî by simply building more wind turbines. The UK, like most nations, doesn't have the topography for much hydro. That leaves one good option: nuclear. 

Building nuclear power stations now ‚Äî and in huge numbers ‚Äî is the single biggest thing we can do to sensibly achieve net zero. 
"
column5:
wind turbines do not replace fossil fuels; they displace fossil fuels only when wind conditions allow them to operate, which is not all the time. during calm weather, especially in the british winter, wind generation drops significantly, forcing reliance on gas in the absence of always-available energy sources like nuclear and hydroelectric power. this reliance makes carbon emissions heavily dependent on weather conditions, which is unsustainable.

this issue cannot be resolved by simply increasing the number of wind turbines. the uk, like most countries, lacks the geographical features required for extensive hydroelectric power. as a result, the most viable solution is nuclear power. building nuclear power stations at scale and doing so immediately is the most effective action the uk can take to achieve net-zero carbon emissions in a practical and reliable manner.

the bornholm energy island is expected to require massive state subsidies.  

this stands in stark contrast to what danish citizens were promised by politicians. it has always been a fundamental requirement that energy island projects must be economically viable. if the project is to move forward politically, there needs to be a clear explanation as to why it is now ‚Äì unlike previously ‚Äì acceptable for the project to rely on state support.  

the fact that two-thirds of the electricity from the energy island is expected to be exported to germany only raises further questions about why danish taxpayers should fund it.

column3:
üö®üá©üá∞Denmark's futuristic North Sea Energy Island project has been delayed, once again. There are several reasons for this. Costs are escalating andüáßüá™Belgium is scared. üá©üá™Germany could be another partner, but it takes time to build energy interdependencies.
This is the second time in recent history that the North Sea Energy Island, a project that is aimed at building an artificial island in the North Sea and using it to collect and distribute electricity generated by offshore wind turbines to countries in the region, is delayed.
This time, the Danish government has more negative tones than in the past. According to Copenhagen, the project won't see the light of the day until 2036, three years after the already-delayed inauguration, announced a few years back.
Two issues are undermining its realisation. The first one is the increase in costs, expected to be around $30 billion. Yes, it doesn't come cheap to foster wind energy, not even in the North Sea. Moreover, costs increase are affecting critical raw materials, as well as impacting interest rates, both influencing the project. Also, Belgium, a partner which should import green electricity from the North Sea Energy Island, is scared by the costs and the government is more and more uncertain about joining it. Instead, Berlin has signalled its interest, but could Germany's economy take such a risk?
column5: denmark's north sea energy island project has been delayed again due to escalating costs and belgium's hesitance. germany might join, but building energy interdependencies takes time. the project, aimed at distributing electricity from offshore wind turbines, won't be completed until 2036, three years later than previously announced. increased costs, including $30 billion for the project and rising raw material prices and interest rates, are major issues. belgium is uncertain about joining due to these costs, while germany has shown interest but faces economic risks.

column3: "Let us be complete in the justifications. Belgium is still willing to connect to the island and to pay its share of the interconnector but why should a third party country participate in the financing of the island, of the windfarms connected to the island or in the connections of those same windfarms to the island???? If Denmark wants to realize its export potential of excess capacity and trade a 'commodity' (electrons), it should finance the 'mining' and transformation of this commodity by itself. The export infrastructure (interconnector) can then be partially financed by the receiving party. This only seems logical."
column5: belgium is still willing to connect to denmark's energy island and pay its share of the interconnector costs, but why should a third-party country finance the island itself, or the wind farms connected to it, or the connections between them? if denmark wants to capitalize on its export potential by trading 'electrons' as a commodity, it should bear the cost of 'mining' and transforming this commodity itself. the export infrastructure, such as the interconnector, can then be partially financed by the receiving party. this seems like the most logical approach.

column3: "Today we all know that wind power technology is developed, matured and available. Our primary objective should now be to focus on how we can effectively reduce our total load on the climate. Construction of very expensive energy consuming artificial islands represents in itself only a further load on the climate. They are more and less isolated centralized vulnerable platforms for the technologies and equipment which produce the green energy. We urgently need to direct our focus more on efficiency and decentralized direct electrification. This is the effective available low-hanging fruit. We need to increase our focus on our total load on the climate, now and in the future. The reality is that we can develop energy technologies and infrastructures which are more reliable, safe, energy-effective and cost-effective than these vulnerable and expensive artificial islands. As we all know, the money can only be used once. Development of new and alternative energy technologies and infrastructures urgently need financial support. However, we have to do it clever. Not by letting us be seduced by glamorosity, hype, and confirmation bias."
column5: wind power technology is already well-developed and available. now, our focus should be on how to reduce our overall climate impact. building expensive, energy-consuming artificial islands adds unnecessary strain on the climate. these islands would become isolated, centralized, and vulnerable platforms for the technologies generating green energy. instead, we should focus on improving efficiency and decentralized electrification, which are more effective and cost-efficient solutions. we must direct our attention to reducing the total load on the climate, both now and in the future. we can create more reliable, safe, energy-efficient, and cost-effective energy infrastructures than these expensive islands. the reality is that money is limited, and we need to wisely invest in new, alternative technologies that will have the most significant impact, avoiding being swayed by glamour or hype.
column13: Are there more cost-effective ways to reach the emissions targets?

And yes, that is risky and sometimes projects will fail. column5: there‚Äôs a lot of negativity surrounding this project, but i wonder why? yes, the island will be more expensive and delayed, but instead of being negative, we should celebrate denmark's efforts. why? because denmark is one of the few countries in the world that is actually trying something innovative. yes, it‚Äôs risky, and some projects might fail, but the mindset of trying something new, rather than simply copying existing ideas, is something we should commend.

column3: ‚ÄúDenmark‚Äôs Energy Island Remains a Fairytale. Yesterday, Danish Minister of Climate Lars Aagaard announced that Denmark‚Äôs long-awaited Energy Island in the North Sea will be postponed by at least three years. The project was estimated to cost around $30 billion and finished by 2033. The Danish government had hoped to secure investment from Belgium for the project, but has now abandoned that effort. The government will now seek to involve Germany as a co-investor, why the Island will now be ready in 2036 at its earliest. Last year The Danish Energy Agency disclosed the Island needing at least $8 billion in state subsidies to become a reality. Something that came as a surprise, as the project was promised to be build on market terms without state involvement. In the meantime Denmark‚Äôs latest offshore tender of 6 GW has been postponed as well until next year. It‚Äôs expected for these offshore parks to finished by 2030. Latest analysis by PwC shows cost of offshore wind in Denmark has skyrocketed the last few years. From 2021 to 2023 prices have risen by 30-40% making it uneconomical to invest in offshore at the moment. All in all, Denmark‚Äôs ambition to build 10‚Äôs of GW offshore in the North Sea in the next decades is hanging by a thread."
column5: denmark's energy island is facing delays. the project, once expected to be finished by 2033 with an estimated cost of $30 billion, will now be postponed by at least three years. the government had hoped to secure investment from belgium, but those efforts have been abandoned, and now germany will be sought as a co-investor. this means the island will likely be completed no earlier than 2036. additionally, the danish energy agency has revealed that the project will need at least $8 billion in state subsidies to become viable‚Äîsomething that contradicts earlier promises of the island being built on market terms without state funding. meanwhile, denmark‚Äôs latest offshore wind tender has also been postponed, with completion expected by 2030. offshore wind costs have soared by 30-40% from 2021 to 2023, making such investments unappealing at present. denmark‚Äôs ambitious plans for offshore wind in the north sea are now in jeopardy.
column13: How to finance the energy islands?

column3: "The artificial island isolated rated is a big CO2 emitting activity during its construction. It is not sustainable and not green in itself. It has, as an imposing artificial island, become incredible hyped and quite strangely popular. However, it is probably a big waste of money considering how many off shore windmills, solar plants, heat pumps, etc we could get for the same amount and much faster, representing real green and sustainable initiatives. The artificial islands are overall weak analysed, very complex and over-optimistic projects, with many uncertainties and trade-offs. Ther exist today large potential competition from other countries, who dont need to build expensive artificial islands to make green fuels, because they have far more suitable land-based options. Finally, the big question is, if it will be the Danish taxpayers who in the end will have to cover the deficit business?"
column5: the construction of artificial islands is a co2-intensive process that isn‚Äôt inherently sustainable or green. despite the growing hype around these islands, they represent a poor financial investment when you consider how much offshore wind, solar power, heat pumps, and other true sustainable technologies could be developed for the same cost and at a faster pace. these artificial islands have been poorly analyzed, are complex, and overly optimistic projects fraught with uncertainties and trade-offs. furthermore, other countries may have a competitive advantage because they don‚Äôt need to rely on costly artificial islands for green fuel production, as they have far more suitable land-based options. the ultimate concern is whether the danish taxpayers will be left to cover any financial shortfalls in this venture.
column13: Are there more cost-effective ways to reach the emissions targets?

column3: "Wind turbines have a rather short life span in sea/costal conditions (water+salt) and will need to be replaced every few years, that creates a lot of scrap and huge operating costs. Wind energy itself is rather unreliable, as there is no power without wind, also with winds too strong turbine needs to engage breaks not to self-destruct and hence doesn't produce any electricity either. Without means to store this energy, and lithium-ion batteries are not the way - super toxic, it is not the technology of the future."
column5: wind turbines have a relatively short lifespan in coastal and sea conditions (water and salt), requiring frequent replacements, which leads to significant waste and high operating costs. wind energy is unreliable since there is no power when there is no wind, and during strong winds, turbines must engage brakes to avoid damage, preventing electricity generation. moreover, without efficient storage solutions, relying on lithium-ion batteries is not a sustainable option due to their toxicity, making them unsuitable for the future.

column5: instead of focusing on large-scale wind or nuclear energy, why not look into deep geothermal energy? texas is already leading the way in this field, and while iceland has been doing this for years, new technology is allowing us to access even deeper sources of geothermal heat (energy). this could provide all the energy we need.
column13: Are there more cost-effective ways to reach the emissions targets?

column3: "Today we all know that wind power technology is developed, matured and available. Our primary objective should now be to focus on how we can effectively reduce our total load on the climate. Construction of very expensive energy consuming artificial islands represents in itself only a further load on the climate. They are more and less isolated centralized vulnerable platforms for the technologies and equipment which produce the green energy. We urgently need to direct our focus more on efficiency and decentralized direct electrification. This is the effective available low-hanging fruit. We need to increase our focus on our total load on the climate, now and in the future. The reality is that we can develop energy technologies and infrastructures which are more reliable, safe, energy-effective and cost-effective than these vulnerable and expensive artificial islands. As we all know, the money can only be used once. Development of new and alternative energy technologies and infrastructures urgently need financial support. However, we have to do it clever. Not by letting us be seduced by glamorosity, hype, and confirmation bias."
column5: wind power technology is already well-developed and available. now, our focus should be on how to reduce our overall climate impact. building expensive, energy-consuming artificial islands adds unnecessary strain on the climate. these islands would become isolated, centralized, and vulnerable platforms for the technologies generating green energy. instead, we should focus on improving efficiency and decentralized electrification, which are more effective and cost-efficient solutions. we must direct our attention to reducing the total load on the climate, both now and in the future. we can create more reliable, safe, energy-efficient, and cost-effective energy infrastructures than these expensive islands. the reality is that money is limited, and we need to wisely invest in new, alternative technologies that will have the most significant impact, avoiding being swayed by glamour or hype.
column13: Are there more cost-effective ways to reach the emissions targets?

column3: "In the reactions there are lots of negativities. I always think why? Yes, the island is going to be more expensive and will be realized with a delay. But instead of being negative we should applaud for Denmark. Why? Because it is one of the few countries in the World which is actually trying something new. And yes, that is risky and sometimes projects will fail. But the attitude of trying to do something new (instead of continuously copying existing things and talking the same as others did) is something we should applaud for."
column5: there‚Äôs a lot of negativity surrounding this project, but i wonder why? yes, the island will be more expensive and delayed, but instead of being negative, we should celebrate denmark's efforts. why? because denmark is one of the few countries in the world that is actually trying something innovative. yes, it‚Äôs risky, and some projects might fail, but the mindset of trying something new, rather than simply copying existing ideas, is something we should commend.

column3: ‚ÄúDenmark‚Äôs Energy Island Remains a Fairytale. Yesterday, Danish Minister of Climate Lars Aagaard announced that Denmark‚Äôs long-awaited Energy Island in the North Sea will be postponed by at least three years. The project was estimated to cost around $30 billion and finished by 2033. The Danish government had hoped to secure investment from Belgium for the project, but has now abandoned that effort. The government will now seek to involve Germany as a co-investor, why the Island will now be ready in 2036 at its earliest. Last year The Danish Energy Agency disclosed the Island needing at least $8 billion in state subsidies to become a reality. Something that came as a surprise, as the project was promised to be build on market terms without state involvement. In the meantime Denmark‚Äôs latest offshore tender of 6 GW has been postponed as well until next year. It‚Äôs expected for these offshore parks to finished by 2030. Latest analysis by PwC shows cost of offshore wind in Denmark has skyrocketed the last few years. From 2021 to 2023 prices have risen by 30-40% making it uneconomical to invest in offshore at the moment. All in all, Denmark‚Äôs ambition to build 10‚Äôs of GW offshore in the North Sea in the next decades is hanging by a thread."
column5: denmark's energy island is facing delays. the project, once expected to be finished by 2033 with an estimated cost of $30 billion, will now be postponed by at least three years. the government had hoped to secure investment from belgium, but those efforts have been abandoned, and now germany will be sought as a co-investor. this means the island will likely be completed no earlier than 2036. additionally, the danish energy agency has revealed that the project will need at least $8 billion in state subsidies to become viable‚Äîsomething that contradicts earlier promises of the island being built on market terms without state funding. meanwhile, denmark‚Äôs latest offshore wind tender has also been postponed, with completion expected by 2030. offshore wind costs have soared by 30-40% from 2021 to 2023, making such investments unappealing at present. denmark‚Äôs ambitious plans for offshore wind in the north sea are now in jeopardy.

column3: "The artificial island isolated rated is a big CO2 emitting activity during its construction. It is not sustainable and not green in itself. It has, as an imposing artificial island, become incredible hyped and quite strangely popular. However, it is probably a big waste of money considering how many off shore windmills, solar plants, heat pumps, etc we could get for the same amount and much faster, representing real green and sustainable initiatives. The artificial islands are overall weak analysed, very complex and over-optimistic projects, with many uncertainties and trade-offs. Ther exist today large potential competition from other countries, who dont need to build expensive artificial islands to make green fuels, because they have far more suitable land-based options. Finally, the big question is, if it will be the Danish taxpayers who in the end will have to cover the deficit business?"
column5: the construction of artificial islands is a co2-intensive process that isn‚Äôt inherently sustainable or green. despite the growing hype around these islands, they represent a poor financial investment when you consider how much offshore wind, solar power, heat pumps, and other true sustainable technologies could be developed for the same cost and at a faster pace. these artificial islands have been poorly analyzed, are complex, and overly optimistic projects fraught with uncertainties and trade-offs. furthermore, other countries may have a competitive advantage because they don‚Äôt need to rely on costly artificial islands for green fuel production, as they have far more suitable land-based options. the ultimate concern is whether the danish taxpayers will be left to cover any financial shortfalls in this venture.

column3: "Wind turbines have a rather short life span in sea/costal conditions (water+salt) and will need to be replaced every few years, that creates a lot of scrap and huge operating costs. Wind energy itself is rather unreliable, as there is no power without wind, also with winds too strong turbine needs to engage breaks not to self-destruct and hence doesn't produce any electricity either. Without means to store this energy, and lithium-ion batteries are not the way - super toxic, it is not the technology of the future."
column5: wind turbines have a relatively short lifespan in coastal and sea conditions (water and salt), requiring frequent replacements, which leads to significant waste and high operating costs. wind energy is unreliable since there is no power when there is no wind, and during strong winds, turbines must engage brakes to avoid damage, preventing electricity generation. moreover, without efficient storage solutions, relying on lithium-ion batteries is not a sustainable option due to their toxicity, making them unsuitable for the future.

Die Facharbeitsgruppe f√ºr Regionalplanung und Energiewende des Landesverbands Erneuerbare Energien Mecklenburg-Vorpommern (LEE MV) kommt in einem neuen Diskussionspapier zu ern√ºchterndem Ergebnis. Von den 470 Bestandsanlagen k√∂nnen m√∂glicherweise lediglich 29 uneingeschr√§nkt gegen neue, leistungsst√§rkere Windenergieanlagen (WEA) ausgetauscht werden.

Dem Diskussionspapier zufolge droht ein massiver R√ºckgang im Bereich der erneuerbaren Energieproduktion in Westmecklenburg. Die Facharbeitsgruppe des LEE MV untersuchte, wie viele der aktuell betriebenen WEA in welchem Zeitraum gegen neue, leistungsst√§rkere ausgetauscht, also repowert werden k√∂nnen. Entsprechend dem Diskussionspapier werden von den aktuell 470 Bestandsanlagen insgesamt 283 Windenergieanlagen bis Ende 2030 das zwanzigste Betriebsjahr √ºberschritten haben und aus der EEG-F√∂rderung fallen. Unter Beachtung der in der Analyse angesetzten Methodik sind von diesen 283 WEA jedoch nur 29 WEA uneingeschr√§nkt bis 2030 repowerbar.

‚ÄûEin Repowering ist nur in Gebieten mit entsprechendem Bauplanungsrecht f√ºr neue Windenergieanlagen umsetzbar‚Äú, erl√§utert Martin M√ºller, Leiter der Facharbeitsgruppe. Gegenw√§rtig beinhaltet die Teilfortschreibung in Westmecklenburg 47 zuk√ºnftige Windeignungsgebiete. Insbesondere die k√ºrzlich beschlossene Streichung diverser potenzieller Repowering-Gebiete wirkt sich negativ auf das gesamte Repowering-Potenzial in Westmecklenburg aus.

‚ÄûIn allen vier Planungsregionen wurden bisher viel zu wenig Fl√§chen f√ºr die Windkraftnutzung ausgewiesen. Deshalb k√∂nnen auch die M√∂glichkeiten des Repowerings (alte, kleine WEA werden durch gr√∂√üere ersetzt) kaum genutzt werden‚Äú, unterstreicht Johann-Georg Jaeger, Vorsitzender des LEE MV. ‚ÄûMit den geplanten ca. 0,7 Prozent der Landesfl√§che, in denen die Windkraftnutzung erm√∂glicht werden soll, verfehlen wir die klima- und energiepolitische Zielsetzung der Landesregierung Mecklenburg-Vorpommerns! Die Windenergie an Land ben√∂tigt kurzfristig mindestens 1,2 Prozent und mittelfristig 2,0 Prozent der Landesfl√§che, ansonsten schaffen wir unsere Klimaschutzziele nicht.‚Äú, kommentiert Jaeger die Gesamtsituation.

Die Planungsregion Westmecklenburg ist eine von vier Regionalplanungsregionen in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. Sie umfasst die Landkreise Nordwestmecklenburg und Ludwigslust-Parchim sowie die Landeshauptstadt Schwerin.
column5: i, believe that repowering of wind energy installations can only be implemented in areas with the appropriate building planning regulations for new wind energy facilities. currently, the partial update for westmecklenburg includes 47 future wind energy areas. however, the recent removal of several potential repowering areas has negatively affected the overall repowering potential in westmecklenburg.

column3:
Die Energiewende ‚Äì ein komplexes Puzzle!

Die Energiewende ist zweifelsohne eine der gr√∂√üten Herausforderungen unserer Zeit. Die Umstellung von fossilen Brennstoffen auf erneuerbare Energien erfordert ein komplexes Zusammenspiel verschiedener Ma√ünahmen, Technologien und gesellschaftlicher Ver√§nderungen. Dabei bietet sich das Bild eines Puzzles als passende Metapher an. üß© 

√Ñhnlich wie bei einem Puzzle ist die Energiewende zu Beginn ein scheinbares Chaos. Eine Vielzahl von Komponenten, wie Sonnenenergie, Windkraft, Biomasse und weitere, m√ºssen in das Gesamtkonzept integriert werden. Es bedarf Geduld und einer sicheren Hand, um die richtigen L√∂sungen zu finden und die Einzelteile sinnvoll zusammenzuf√ºgen. üèóÔ∏è

Die Energiewende erfordert zudem eine ruhige und zielgerichtete Herangehensweise. Genauso wie bei einem komplizierten Puzzle ist es wichtig, nicht die Geduld zu verlieren und beharrlich an der Umsetzung zu arbeiten. üí™üèª

Die Vielfalt der eingesetzten ‚Äûguten Attribute‚Äú in Form von Innovationen, intelligenten Systemen, politischen Entscheidungen und dem Engagement der Bev√∂lkerung ist entscheidend, um das gro√üe und ganze Bild der Energiewende zu formen. Nur wenn all diese Elemente harmonisch zusammenarbeiten, kann die Energiewende und jedes Puzzle seine ganze Sch√∂nheit entfalten. üåü
column5:
we think, that the energy transition is a complex puzzle!

the energy transition is undoubtedly one of the greatest challenges of our time. the switch from fossil fuels to renewable energies requires a complex interplay of various measures, technologies and social changes. the image of a puzzle is a suitable metaphor. 

similar to a puzzle, the energy transition is initially an apparent chaos. a large number of components, such as solar energy, wind power, biomass and others, must be integrated into the overall concept. it takes patience and a steady hand to find the right solutions and put the individual pieces together in a meaningful way. 

the energy transition also requires a calm and goal-oriented approach. just like with a complicated puzzle, it is important not to lose patience and to work persistently on implementation.

the variety of "good attributes" used in the form of innovations, intelligent systems, political decisions and the commitment of the population is crucial to shaping the big picture of the energy transition. only when all these elements work together harmoniously can the energy transition and each puzzle unfold its full beauty.

green ammonia production on floating offshore systems is definitely a promising approach: the deadbeat argument of some politicians (electrolysis is too inefficient in terms of utilization) should be thrown in the trash the moment floating systems are ready for production... and everything that remains liquid under atmospheric pressure , helps to decouple energy production and consumption over time: i have loved this idea since i read about the floatant joint project of european technical universities.

Fremsyn og tro p√• fremtiden p√• Bornholm

Bornholm er et vigtigt udviklingssted for vedvarende energi ‚Äì et levende laboratorium, hvor vi bidrager til den globale omstilling og skaber v√¶kst og v√¶rdi. 

DTU - Technical University of Denmark har v√¶ret til stede p√• Bornholm i n√¶sten 20 √•r, hvor vi har samarbejdet om fremtidens energisystem, bl.a. med energilagring, integration af vindkraft, intelligente fjernvarmesystemer, fleksibelt forbrug og meget mere. 

Folketingets beslutning i 2020 om at udvikle Bornholm til Energi√∏ Bornholm understreger Bornholms vigtige status og ikke mindst, hvordan √∏en fra sin position i √òsters√∏en vil kunne levere vigtig gr√∏n energi til Europa og blive et centralt europ√¶isk energicenter. 

‚ÄùFremsyn og tro p√• fremtiden‚Äù ‚Äì det var ordene, da man tilbage i 1909 p√• Bornholm anlagde R√∏nne Elv√¶rk, som S√∏ren M√∏ller Christensen, Baltic Energy Island fremh√¶vede.

Mere end 100 √•r efter g√•r de samme tanker igen: R√∏nne Elv√¶rk st√•r for at blive en fantastisk ramme, et innovationscenter for studerende og forskere, der arbejder med energi√∏er: Vi skal have endnu flere uddannelses- og forskningsaktiviteter p√• Bornholm ‚Äì flere DTU-studerende p√• Bornholm.

For det er oplagt for DTU at v√¶re til stede p√• Bornholm, at have et residential college til studerende og forskere. Det giver mening: For DTU, for Bornholm, for Danmark ‚Äì ja, for Europa. 

Dagen b√∏d p√• samtaler og debat med de mange involverede, de vigtige partnerskaber, som hj√¶lper vores gr√∏nne fremtid p√• vej ‚Äì politikere, h√•ndv√¶rkere, myndigheder, erhverv og organisationer ‚Äì og rykker Bornholm videre fra test√∏ til v√¶kst. 

Og s√• havde jeg ogs√• ‚Äì sammen med S√∏ren M√∏ller Christensen, Claus M. Andersen, Bornholms Energi & Forsyning, Jacob √òstergaard, DTU og Martin Christian Ransted, Bornholms Elektromotor ApS ‚Äì den store forn√∏jelse at pr√¶sentere tiltag, tanker og visioner for D.M. Kongen og Dronningen p√• R√∏nne Elv√¶rk.

column5:
the bornholm energy island project represents a crucial opportunity that dtu has been preparing for nearly 20 years. dtu has been actively collaborating on bornholm in developing future energy systems, including energy storage, wind power integration, smart district heating systems, and flexible consumption solutions.

the danish parliament's 2020 decision to develop bornholm as an energy island validates bornholm's strategic importance. from bornholm's position in the baltic sea, the island will deliver vital green energy to europe and become a central european energy hub.

the historic r√∏nne power plant will be transformed into an innovation center for students and researchers working on energy islands. dtu must expand its educational and research activities on bornholm by bringing more dtu students to the island. dtu's plan to establish a residential college for students and researchers on bornholm makes perfect sense for dtu, bornholm, denmark, and europe as a whole.

the project's success depends on crucial partnerships between politicians, craftspeople, authorities, businesses, and organizations, which will help transform bornholm from a test island to a growth center. dtu is committed to maintaining its presence on bornholm and contributing to this green future.
column13: Who benefits socially and economically from energy islands? Is it fair?

column3:
Denmark's part of its largest-ever hashtag#offshorewind auction concluded with a (not so) surprising outcome: no bids were submitted, putting the country's ambitious offshore wind projects on uncertain ground. The reasons?
>> Pure merchant exposure amid soaring raw material costs.
>> Heavy penalties for delayed grid connections, adding more financial risk.
>> Cost burden for wind developers associated with the obligation to build the connection line (deep connection setup) 
>> Co-ownership rule, granting the State 20% of project value.

What ripple effects can be expected?
>> The lack of bids jeopardizes financing for the planned 3GW Bornholm Energy Island initiative
>> The overall situation leaves Denmark at risk of missing its renewable energy targets.
>> Denmark‚Äôs hydrogen goals are also under threat. The nation aims for 4-6 GW of electrolysis capacity by 2030. The no-bid auction, combined with the recent announcement from the TSO of long delays in the construction of the DK-DE hydrogen pipeline, casts serious doubt on Denmark‚Äôs ability to deliver on its hydrogen ambitions in time. 
Denmark faces a critical moment for its renewable energy vision, with both offshore wind and hashtag#hydrogen infrastructure hanging in the balance if no strong supportive solutions are offered by the government.
column5:
no developers submitted bids for denmark's largest-ever offshore wind auction, putting denmark's renewable energy future at risk. this outcome, while not entirely surprising, stems from several critical issues:

the projects expose developers to full market risks at a time when raw material costs are extremely high. the government has imposed severe financial penalties for any delays in grid connections. developers must bear the full cost burden of building connection lines to the grid under the deep connection setup. additionally, denmark's state co-ownership rule requires developers to give up 20% of project value to the state.

these challenges create cascading effects that threaten multiple strategic initiatives. the 3gw bornholm energy island project may now struggle to secure financing. denmark will likely miss its renewable energy targets. the country's goal of developing 4-6 gw of electrolysis capacity by 2030 is in serious jeopardy, especially given the transmission system operator's recent announcement of major delays in constructing the denmark-germany hydrogen pipeline.

unless the danish government implements strong supportive measures, both offshore wind development and hydrogen infrastructure ambitions are at serious risk of failure. this represents a critical turning point for denmark's entire renewable energy strategy.
column13: How to finance the energy islands?

Wo f√ºhrt uns das hin?
1. Die Energieinseln werden staatliche Beihilfen in Milliardenh√∂he ben√∂tigen.

Was f√ºr eine spannende #Offshore-Woche! Erst der #NorthSeaSummit23 in Ostende, jetzt die Jahreskonferenz von #WindEurope in Kopenhagen. Dort sind wir noch bis einschlie√ülich morgen mit Elia und Energinet mit unserem Gemeinschaftsstand pr√§sent. Gemeinsam mit Energinet wollen wir von #50Hertz auf der Insel Bornholm ein Stromdrehkreuz errichten. Dort soll Wechselstrom in Hochspannungsgleichstrom (HG√ú) umgewandelt und bedarfsgerecht verteilt werden. √úber 525-kV-See- und Landkabelsysteme wird der Strom zu Umspannwerken auf der d√§nischen Insel Seeland und nach Mecklenburg-Vorpommern transportiert. what an exciting #offshore week! first, the #northseasummit23 in ostend, and now the annual conference of #windeurope in copenhagen. we will be present here until tomorrow with elia and energinet at our joint booth. today, crown prince frederik of denmark visited to observe how our three energy islands‚Äîprincess elisabeth island (elia), bornholm energy island (#50hertz-energinet), and north sea energy island (energinet)‚Äîwill help unlock the #offshore potential in the north and baltic seas. this marks another innovative step towards ensuring #supplysecurity and #climeneutrality in europe.

together with energinet, we at #50hertz aim to build a power hub on bornholm island. there, alternating current (ac) will be converted into high-voltage direct current (hvdc) and distributed according to demand. through 525 kv offshore and land cable systems, electricity will be transported to substations on the danish island of zealand and to mecklenburg-vorpommern. this will lead to another innovative project, following the kriegers flak - #combinedgridsolution (kf cgs), to jointly integrate green #electricity generated by offshore wind into energy systems across borders‚Äîfurther connecting europe's power grid. #europeanoffshoregrids

column5: artificial islands are becoming increasingly important alongside natural islands. the north sea represents europe's premier and most secure green power plant, which is why denmark is pursuing an energy island project there. this concept isn't entirely new - during the 1960s oil crisis, similar visions existed with the "labskausdeal" plans to expand hamburg's scharh√∂rn into a major energy hub. while the salzgitter steel industry supported this, other northern stakeholders found it too ambitious and expensive, leading energy-intensive industries from north rhine-westphalia to relocate to belgium and the netherlands instead. hamburg's subsequent focus on the elbe metropolis and hafencity, with multiple river deepening projects, has proven costly for german taxpayers without offering real future prospects. now, we're seeing a revival of the energy island concept, with cuxhaven proposing a new multifunctional island project that could address contemporary challenges facing northern germany.
