column3: Energi√∏ Bornholm er et ret komplekst projekt ‚ö°üåç Den nylige rapport fra t√¶nketanken Kraka Economics, med titlen "Energi√∏ Bornholm: En √∏konomisk katastrofe i slowmotion," rejser skarp kritik af energi√∏-projektet. Rapporten om energi√∏en, som er finansieret af Novo Nordisk Foundation, og blev pr√¶senteret ved de √∏konomiske vism√¶nds √•rlige milj√∏√∏konomiske konference i Skodsborg (The Secretariat of the Danish Economic Councils), som jeg deltog i sidste √•r. Selvom rapporten helt rigtigt fremh√¶ver de √∏konomiske udfordringer ved projektet, er de aspekter allerede velkendte. Den tager dog ikke h√∏jde for alle aspekter og minder mest om en generel kritik af offshore vind. Rapporten foresl√•r ikke, hvad der kan g√∏res for at g√∏re projektet rentabelt. Og kravet om rentabilitet fra Danmarks og Tysklands side er stadig tilstede, hvorfor projektet kan skrottes udskydes eller om-designes, hvis ikke det lever op til det. Rapporten foresl√•r heller ikke, hvordan forsyningssikkerheden i √∏vrigt kan l√∏ftes i √òsters√∏regionen. Se interview i link nedenfor. - Som jeg mange gange har p√•peget er en fire-dobling af VE p√• land og udbygning p√• havet langt over hvad vi teknisk kan have i Danmark. I 2030 vil vi v√¶re stort set selvforsynende med str√∏m: 1) Vi skal videre vores VE m√•l, og over i et forbrugsdrevet system, 2) hvor nye elforbrug driver investeringer i den billigste VE. 3) Om energi√∏en er √∏komisk b√¶redygtig skal tryktestes, men produktionen skal matche en eftersp√∏rgsel. Her er det afg√∏rende at integrere teknologier som Power-to-X og datacentre, som kan absorbere den ekstra produktion og reducere brugen af fossile br√¶ndsler i sektorer med h√∏j klimabelastning. 4) Energi√∏ Bornholm handler ikke kun om Danmarks forsyningssikkerhed, men ogs√• om at styrke Europas samlede forsyningssikkerhed. üåçüîå 5) Kritikken af energi√∏ens √∏konomi er berettiget, men det er ogs√• vigtigt at overveje alternative l√∏sninger, s√•som potentialet for at koble energi√∏en p√• netv√¶rk i Sverige eller Polen for at reducere omkostningerne. üèóÔ∏èüí∏ Selvom der er udfordringer forbundet med energi√∏-projektet, er det sandsynligt, at det vil blive realiseret ‚Äì m√•ske med n√∏dvendige justeringer og tilpasninger undervejs - eventuelt udskudt. Det nylige skrinlagte energi√∏-projekt i Nords√∏en er et positivt tegn p√•, at man tilpasser projekterne til de √∏konomiske realiteter i stedet for at tvinge projektet igennem uanset omkostninger. Det er derfor ogs√• positivt at granske √∏konomien. Det √¶ndrer dog ikke p√•, at der √©r rentable og st√∏ttefri offshore m√∏ller i √òsters√∏en, hvorfor energi√∏ Bornholms brogede √∏konomi har mere at g√∏re med designet af parken, end med vindm√∏ller. Forsyningssikkerhed, omkostningseffektivitet, timing og gr√∏n energi til nye forbrug i √òsters√∏regionen er n√∏gleordene for at komme videre. üè¢üîã

column5: i believe that the energy island project at bornholm is highly complex and that recent economic criticisms, such as the report from kraka economics entitled "energi√∏ bornholm: en √∏konomisk katastrofe i slowmotion," although valid in highlighting economic challenges, only address well-known issues and do not offer solutions for enhancing profitability or ensuring regional energy security in the baltic sea. i point out that the report, funded by the novo nordisk foundation and presented at the annual conference organized by the danish economic councils, largely criticizes offshore wind in general rather than addressing the specific design issues of the bornholm energy island project. i insist that to make the project economically viable, we must continue to pursue our renewable energy targets and transition to a consumption-driven system in which investments in the lowest-cost renewable energy are stimulated by growing demand. i argue that it is crucial to integrate innovative technologies, such as power-to-x solutions and data centers, to absorb surplus production and reduce fossil fuel usage in high-emission sectors. i also emphasize that the bornholm project is not solely about securing denmark‚Äôs energy supply, but is equally important for enhancing europe‚Äôs overall energy security. i acknowledge that the economic critiques are justified, yet we must consider alternative strategies, such as connecting the energy island to networks in sweden or poland to lower costs. i further note that while challenges exist, the project is likely to be implemented with the necessary adjustments and potential delays, similar to the positive adjustments seen in the shelved north sea energy island project, which indicates that designs can be adapted to meet economic realities. ultimately, i maintain that the mixed economic performance of the bornholm energy island is more about the design of the wind park than about the fundamental viability of offshore wind technology in the baltic region.

column5: kraka economics states: "the postponement of the energi√∏ bornholm tender is a welcome action because the policymakers urgently need a moment to deliberate. the danish energy authority is reportedly preparing updated calculations that are expected to reveal that the project's already weak economic foundation will deteriorate further due to increasing infrastructure costs. there is a strong likelihood that the planned 6 gw of conventional offshore wind will underperform, thereby failing to generate sufficient financing to support the allocated state subsidy for energi√∏ bornholm. with potential additional support costs rising by 8-10 billion danish kroner and with funding being diverted away from other offshore wind projects, policymakers are now faced with a massive financial gap. this pause in the tender process creates an opportunity for policymakers to take responsibility by thoroughly reconsidering whether to proceed with this economically disastrous project that would impose billions in costs on danish taxpayers. however, it is imperative for policymakers not to delay their decision excessively, as energinet is scheduled to sign contracts with suppliers of cables and transformer stations at the start of the new year. once these contracts are signed, abandoning the project would result in significantly higher costs because rescinding the contracts is not without expense."

column5:
energy islands are innovative projects designed as central hubs for generating electricity from renewable sources in the seas and oceans. these islands are specifically built to harness offshore wind, solar, and tidal energy and act as central stations for offshore wind turbines. one of the most significant projects in this field is the north sea energy island, being developed by denmark, germany, belgium, and the netherlands. this project, as the world‚Äôs largest offshore renewable energy project, is expected to produce 10 gigawatts of wind energy and began in 2024, with completion expected by 2030.

the investment for this project is estimated at over 30 billion euros, covering the construction of offshore infrastructure, installation of wind turbines, and power transmission systems, all of which require precise planning and effective management. for the success of these projects, effective project planning plays a crucial role. given the large scale and technical complexity of such projects, careful planning is needed to manage time, cost, and resources effectively. in this context, project planning professionals must ensure that all activities are coordinated and that the project is completed within the set time and budget.

energy islands offer several benefits:
1. sustainable and clean energy: by generating power from renewable sources, these islands can provide stable and low-cost electricity for millions of people.
2. cost reduction: centralized stations significantly reduce electricity transmission and storage costs.
3. environmental impact: these projects help reduce greenhouse gas emissions and play a vital role in combating climate change.

these energy islands not only contribute to the global development of renewable energy but also guide europe toward a greener and more sustainable future. in this process, project planning plays a fundamental role in achieving these ambitious goals and ensuring their success.

From linkedin poster:
EXPLAINER ‚Äì ENERGY ISLANDS 
Denmark‚Äôs first two energy islands will be located at Bornholm in the Baltic Sea and the North Sea, where an artificial island will be established. The energy islands will provide unprecedented volumes of renewable energy ‚ôª

But what is exactly an energy island? And how does it work? See this explainer, where you can hear about the energy islands and how they function from DTU Professor Jacob √òstergaard. 
Wind energy and energy islands
To achieve a fossil fuel-free society that meets our increasing need for energy, it is necessary to expand the capacity of renewable energy technologies. In this connection, wind energy remains the cheapest energy technology we have available.

Picture of wind turbines lined up at Storeb√¶ltsbroen in Denmark.
More than 40 per cent. of the total Danish electricity production comes from wind turbines, and wind energy therefore constitutes an important element in the restructuring of the energy system, which will ensure that Denmark becomes independent of fossil fuels in 2050.
What is wind energy?
Wind energy is pollution-free energy produced exclusively by means of wind from wind turbines that can be set up both on land and at sea. Carbon is emitted during the production, transport and installation of wind turbines, but this emission is typically earned back within 6-12 months of a wind turbine‚Äôs service life. Wind turbines erected today have a design life of 25 years, but have often been shown to last for 30 years or more.

The global green transition is underway, and wind turbines are increasingly being used as a replacement for fossil-fuel power stations. According to the Danish Energy Agency, more than 40 per cent of Denmark‚Äôs total electricity production derives from wind turbines. Thus wind energy plays the key role in the transformation of Denmark‚Äôs energy system, and in the efforts to ensure that Denmark is carbon-neutral by 2050. 

Today, wind turbines and wind energy account for less than five per cent of the total electricity produced in the world. However, the International Energy Agency estimates that this figure may be as high as 36 per cent by 2050. This will require that we continue to invest in wind turbines and wind technology in the future, so that we can become even better at utilizing wind power‚Äînot just in Denmark, but globally.

How does a wind turbine work?
The wind causes the wind turbine‚Äôs blades to revolve. This transfers energy to the blades. The energy is used to operate a generator installed inside the wind turbine housing (the nacelle). The generator creates current by means of electromagnetic induction, where a magnet is rotated in a chamber with coils. When the magnet rotates, the magnetic field in the coils changes, creating current. The current is usually passed on to the power grid, which forms the system of wires that transport the current out into the consumers‚Äô sockets.

How is electricity from wind turbines utilized?
By far the majority of electricity produced from wind turbines is utilized in the public power grid, from which there are cable connections to most of our neighbouring countries. In 2021, wind energy accounted for 47 per cent of electricity production in Denmark.

The cable connections to other countries ensure that there is always a market for the energy produced. This is also the case when the weather is windy, and we have a surplus of wind energy in the Danish energy system. In addition, the cable connections are designed to ensure that we can import electricity from abroad when we have no wind and thus a deficit of electricity in our energy system.

üå¨Ô∏è Exciting Times Ahead for US Offshore Wind! üåä 
 
As highlighted in the latest 2024 US Offshore Wind Market Report published by Liz Burdock and our great team from Oceantic Network, the #US market is on the cusp of significant growth and development in the coming months. With the market largely stabilizing and returning to growth, there's immense potential for supply chain advancements, increased investment, and a resurgence in shipbuilding activity. 
 
According to the report, in 2024 US states could award up to 1550 MW of new power offtake, with a substantial portion aimed at replenishing lost contracts. Additionally, the forecast indicates a continued rise in approved construction capacity, reaching at least 14.6 GW this year. 
 
Despite facing setbacks, 2023 witnessed pivotal announcements regarding new manufacturing facilities, port infrastructure upgrades, and the introduction of offshore wind vessels. Moreover, states have been diligently working on fostering interstate cooperation frameworks to stabilize regional markets, reduce project costs, and enhance economic benefits. 
 
During my recent visit to the US last week, I was encouraged by the strong commitment from clients and partners to reignite the offshore wind sector. Engaging discussions were held on strategies to overcome challenges and capitalize on opportunities for growth.  
 
While the enthusiasm is high, it's crucial to acknowledge the upcoming uncertainty in the US market in 2024. With the Federal election on the horizon, there's a growing societal critique of offshore wind's impact on electricity bills and concerns about meeting promises on local job creation. 
 
As a member of the Board of Directors for Oceantic Network and with the support of my dedicated team at Ramboll, I am deeply committed to driving the success of US offshore wind. Together, we endeavour to advocate for a more balanced market design and regulatory framework that aligns with broader societal interests, paving the way for a sustainable future. 
 
Let's harness this momentum, address challenges head-on, and collectively contribute to a thriving and sustainable US offshore wind industry! üí®üåé #USOffshoreWind #DecarbonizingForNetZero #PartnerForSustainableChange

Blades, nacelles, towers, foundations, and cables are essential components for any offshore wind project. Yet, even setting these ‚Äúbig ticket items‚Äù aside, the hashtag#US offshore wind supply chain presents immense opportunities for smaller local businesses.
 
In the U.S. offshore wind market, one particular area of opportunity for smaller businesses is hashtag#SecondarySteel. These steel-made subcomponents offer an excellent entry point for local businesses, come with less contractual risk, and in many cases can be completed with existing tooling. Engaging and activating participation of smaller local business is a fundamental element of establishing a sustainable domestic U.S. offshore wind supply chain from the ground up. 

Don't miss the opportunity to gain valuable insights from Tim Fischer, Ramboll's Global Executive Director Wind, who will highlight supply chain opportunities related to secondary steel, and ways businesses can get involved in New Jersey and New York. Tim‚Äôs presentation is scheduled for 1:20 pm on October 28, 2024, at the New Jersey and New York Offshore Wind Supplier Forum in Atlantic City.

In addition, our U.S. offshore wind experts will be present at the American Clean Power Association (ACP) Offshore WINDPOWER Conference & Exhibition from October 28 ‚Äì 30, 2024, in Atlantic City. Come find us at the Pavilion of Denmark or arrange a meeting with Tim Fischer, David VanLuvanee, Brandon W. Burke, or Benjamin Foley, P.E., P.Eng., PMP.
 
Looking forward to connecting with you in Atlantic City!
hashtag#DecarbonizingForNetZero hashtag#ThePartnerForSustainableChange hashtag#WindEnergy hashtag#supplychain

Energy islands are large-scale offshore energy hubs which will enable the massive scaling required for the next generation of offshore wind deployment globally. Energy islands allow for a cost-efficient build-out and integration of offshore wind at a significantly larger scale and in an innovative way.
Copenhagen Energy Islands: An independent development company established as a carve-out of CIP
Copenhagen Energy Islands is established as a carve-out of Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners (‚ÄúCIP‚Äù), a world-leading fund management company within renewable energy. CEI is an independent company majority-owned by CIP and a group of institutional investors. The founding investor group includes major Nordic, European, and North American investors with a track record of investments in renewable energy infrastructure. Among them are PensionDenmark, PFA, SEB, and Andel.

The Energy Island Forum, a partnership uniting key stakeholders engaged in offshore energy hubs, has presented its roadmap in the European Parliament, outlining the critical steps to realize Europe‚Äôs first offshore hubs by 2030 and laying the groundwork to boost long-term innovation and industrial competitiveness.

The initiative details a plan to create the first island by 2030 and further advance the technology to make Offshore Energy Hubs cost-effective and impactful.

‚ÄúThe new roadmap for Europe‚Äôs energy offshore hubs is a positive step in the right direction as it shows firm industrial ambition behind the energy system of the future. The development of energy hubs is pivotal in reaching the EU‚Äôs decarbonization goals for 2050, and Copenhagen Energy Islands is a frontrunner in this development,‚Äù Samuel Magid, Deputy-CEO, Copenhagen Energy Islands at Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners.

Energy islands offer significant benefits for the whole of Europe, securing green and affordable energy. But how do we succeed with fair cost-benefit-sharing when the grid has to be built out, and the first projects are established? That was the talk of the town when Chairman Claus M. Andersen, Board Member Jacob √òstergaard, and CEO S√∏ren M√∏ller Christensen visited Brussels last week. The regional perspective was mentioned many times. We must at least succeed on a regional perspective with collaboration and cost-benefit-sharing around the EU's different Sea Basins. And why not start with the Baltic Sea?
 
Thanks for the great discussions to Sebastian Schulte-Derne from √òrsted, Bernard De Clercq from Elia Group, Valdemar Rosenberg from Energikommiss√¶r Simsons' cabinet, Charlotte Gjedde from DI, Anders Hulgreen Jensen from Green Power Denmark, and from Wind Europe: Vasiliki Klonari, head of energy system integration, Riccardo Longo, offshore grid manager and Mattia Cecchinato, senior adviser offshore wind. 
 
A special thank you to √òrsted and Elia Group for guiding us through their White Paper ‚ÄòMaking Hybrids Happen‚Äô.

And a huge thanks to Casper Andersen from Greater Copenhagen EU Office for all your help during our stay
column5:
baltic energy islands believes that energy islands offer significant benefits for europe, ensuring the provision of green and affordable energy. however, there are challenges regarding the fair distribution of costs and benefits, particularly when it comes to the construction of necessary grids and the establishment of the first projects. the focus of recent discussions in brussels, attended by chairman claus m. andersen, board member jacob √∏stergaard, and ceo s√∏ren m√∏ller christensen, emphasized the importance of a regional approach, particularly with collaboration and cost-sharing across the eu's different sea basins. baltic energy islands advocates for starting this cooperation with the baltic sea region.

baltic energy islands acknowledges the valuable discussions held with key industry figures, including representatives from √∏rsted, elia group, and wind europe, and appreciates the insights shared regarding hybrid projects and offshore wind integration. the company also expresses gratitude to √∏rsted and elia group for their guidance on the white paper ‚Äòmaking hybrids happen‚Äô and to casper andersen from the greater copenhagen eu office for his support during the visit.

column3:
Wind energy and energy islands
To achieve a fossil fuel-free society that meets our increasing need for energy, it is necessary to expand the capacity of renewable energy technologies. In this connection, wind energy remains the cheapest energy technology we have available.

Picture of wind turbines lined up at Storeb√¶ltsbroen in Denmark.
More than 40 per cent. of the total Danish electricity production comes from wind turbines, and wind energy therefore constitutes an important element in the restructuring of the energy system, which will ensure that Denmark becomes independent of fossil fuels in 2050.
What is wind energy?
Wind energy is pollution-free energy produced exclusively by means of wind from wind turbines that can be set up both on land and at sea. Carbon is emitted during the production, transport and installation of wind turbines, but this emission is typically earned back within 6-12 months of a wind turbine‚Äôs service life. Wind turbines erected today have a design life of 25 years, but have often been shown to last for 30 years or more.

The global green transition is underway, and wind turbines are increasingly being used as a replacement for fossil-fuel power stations. According to the Danish Energy Agency, more than 40 per cent of Denmark‚Äôs total electricity production derives from wind turbines. Thus wind energy plays the key role in the transformation of Denmark‚Äôs energy system, and in the efforts to ensure that Denmark is carbon-neutral by 2050. 

Today, wind turbines and wind energy account for less than five per cent of the total electricity produced in the world. However, the International Energy Agency estimates that this figure may be as high as 36 per cent by 2050. This will require that we continue to invest in wind turbines and wind technology in the future, so that we can become even better at utilizing wind power‚Äînot just in Denmark, but globally.

How does a wind turbine work?
The wind causes the wind turbine‚Äôs blades to revolve. This transfers energy to the blades. The energy is used to operate a generator installed inside the wind turbine housing (the nacelle). The generator creates current by means of electromagnetic induction, where a magnet is rotated in a chamber with coils. When the magnet rotates, the magnetic field in the coils changes, creating current. The current is usually passed on to the power grid, which forms the system of wires that transport the current out into the consumers‚Äô sockets.

How is electricity from wind turbines utilized?
By far the majority of electricity produced from wind turbines is utilized in the public power grid, from which there are cable connections to most of our neighbouring countries. In 2021, wind energy accounted for 47 per cent of electricity production in Denmark.

The cable connections to other countries ensure that there is always a market for the energy produced. This is also the case when the weather is windy, and we have a surplus of wind energy in the Danish energy system. In addition, the cable connections are designed to ensure that we can import electricity from abroad when we have no wind and thus a deficit of electricity in our energy system.

Comment: EXPLAINER ‚Äì ENERGY ISLANDS 
Denmark‚Äôs first two energy islands will be located at Bornholm in the Baltic Sea and the North Sea, where an artificial island will be established. The energy islands will provide unprecedented volumes of renewable energy ‚ôª

But what is exactly an energy island? And how does it work? See this explainer, where you can hear about the energy islands and how they function from DTU Professor Jacob √òstergaard.
column5:
the development of energy islands is a critical step toward meeting denmark's goal of becoming fossil fuel-free by 2050. denmark has long been a leader in wind energy, with over 40% of the country‚Äôs electricity coming from wind turbines. wind energy plays a vital role in transforming denmark‚Äôs energy system and in the global green transition.

energy islands, which will be located in the baltic sea at bornholm and in the north sea with an artificial island, are designed to significantly increase the production of renewable energy. these islands will harness large amounts of offshore wind power, far beyond what denmark has been able to achieve with existing wind farms.

the concept of energy islands involves setting up an infrastructure capable of producing renewable energy at a much larger scale. by using advanced wind turbines, we aim to expand denmark's capacity to export green energy to neighboring countries while also ensuring that energy is available even when weather conditions lead to lower wind energy production. this shift is essential for meeting both denmark‚Äôs energy needs and its ambition to be a carbon-neutral country by 2050.

column3:
Last week I had the honor to launch Energy Island Forum‚Äôs first roadmap, ‚ÄúMAKING ENERGY ISLANDS A SUCCESS‚Äù at the European Parliament in an event hosted by MEP Niels Fuglsang (Denmark) and co-hosted by MEP Borys Budka (Poland), both members of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE). It was a great event, with more than 60 participants from 12 countries, a clear indication of how much attention energy islands attract. 

While they face many risks, and the road to developing the first projects is not linear or smooth, the biggest risk we face is inaction!  Failing to combat climate change and allowing non-European countries to lead in technological advancements will leave us dependent on their achievements.

We must embrace a "good enough" approach and complete the first energy islands by 2030 or shortly after. These initial projects will serve as stepping stones for future innovations in energy islands and I am convinced that industry and academia will use the learnings to make the next energy islands (or offshore energy hubs, my preferred terminology) better and more efficient!

While I thoroughly enjoyed presenting the roadmap and moderating the panel, it really is the result of a collective effort from a significant number of experts from the Energy Island Forum. I have the privilege to chair the group, together with Anders Vedel, but the credit is all theirs!
column5:
last week, i had the honor of launching the energy island forum's first roadmap, ‚Äúmaking energy islands a success,‚Äù at the european parliament, hosted by mep niels fuglsang and co-hosted by mep borys budka, both members of the itre committee. the strong turnout, with over 60 participants from 12 countries, highlights the significant attention energy islands are receiving.

energy islands face numerous challenges, and the path to their development is neither linear nor smooth. however, the greatest risk we face is inaction. if we fail to combat climate change and allow non-european countries to lead in technological advancements, europe will become dependent on their achievements.

we need to adopt a "good enough" mindset to ensure the first energy islands are operational by 2030 or soon after. these initial projects will lay the foundation for future innovations in energy islands‚Äîor offshore energy hubs, as i prefer to call them‚Äîenabling the industry and academia to improve efficiency and performance in subsequent projects.

the roadmap i presented is the result of a collective effort by the energy island forum experts. while i have the privilege of co-chairing the group with anders vedel, the credit belongs entirely to the dedicated team behind this initiative.

column3:
Belgium starts building World‚Äôs first artificial energy island
The world‚Äôs first artificial energy island is being built off the coast of Belgium and will serve as future interconnector between countries as well.

Summary: Belgium has begun construction on the world‚Äôs first artificial energy island, named Princess Elisabeth Island, located 45 kilometers off its coast. This groundbreaking project aims to enhance renewable energy usage and facilitate energy exchange between countries, signifying a major advancement in sustainable energy infrastructure.

Project Details:

Location and Construction: The island is being constructed in the Princess Elisabeth Zone, a designated area for offshore renewable energy in the North Sea.

Funding: The project benefits from a 100 million euro grant from the European Union‚Äôs COVID-19 recovery fund.

Infrastructure: The island will integrate high-voltage direct current (HVDC) and alternating current (HVAC) systems to distribute energy generated from offshore wind farms to the grid.

Caisson Construction: Essential to the island‚Äôs structure, these watertight concrete blocks are meticulously crafted over three months and will form the perimeter of the island.

Innovative Aspects:

Hybrid Interconnectors: The island will pioneer the use of hybrid interconnectors, which are crucial for connecting with wind farms and facilitating energy trades between nations.

Material Use: Approximately 2.3 million cubic meters of sand and large concrete caissons are utilized to construct the island‚Äôs base and walls.
Strategic Importance:

Energy Independence: The project is part of Belgium's broader strategy to reduce dependency on fossil fuels and shift towards renewable energy sources.

Regional Impact: Prime Minister Alexander De Croo highlighted that the North Sea is poised to become a central hub for Europe's energy independence, reinforcing Belgium's leadership in offshore wind energy.

Projected Timeline:
Completion: The physical structure of the island is expected to be completed by 2026, with the operational phase targeted for 2030.

This initiative not only represents a significant technological leap but also aligns with global efforts towards sustainability and energy security, positioning Belgium at the forefront of renewable energy innovation.
column5:
belgium has started constructing the world‚Äôs first artificial energy island, princess elisabeth island, located 45 kilometers off the belgian coast in the north sea. this project is a significant step forward in renewable energy infrastructure, aiming to enhance renewable energy usage and facilitate international energy exchange.  

the island, supported by a ‚Ç¨100 million grant from the eu‚Äôs covid-19 recovery fund, will feature integrated hvdc and hvac systems to distribute energy from offshore wind farms to the grid. hybrid interconnectors will enable connections with wind farms and energy trade between countries.  

the construction involves innovative methods, including 2.3 million cubic meters of sand and concrete caissons to form its base and walls. strategically, this project reduces belgium‚Äôs reliance on fossil fuels and positions the north sea as a hub for europe‚Äôs energy independence.  

the island‚Äôs physical structure is expected to be completed by 2026, with operations commencing in 2030. this groundbreaking initiative underscores belgium‚Äôs leadership in renewable energy and its commitment to sustainability and energy security.
column13: Geopolitics and energy independence: can we avoid relying on others for our energy supply?

column3:
Friends Of the Earth have undertaken a study (along with the University of Exeter) to identify land that could be most suitable for new onshore renewable energy in England: this includes an interactive map that identifies key areas that could potentially generate the most sustainable energy e.g. wind, solar etc.

Interesting to read the full report and see what parameters that they have used for site identification - good that they have excluded AONBs, National Parks and prime agricultural land, but interested to also see that they have used a 1km buffer around designated heritage assets, so at least there is some consideration of the historic environment in their analyses. 

Speaking from my own experience, 1km is a very arbitary buffer and won't be appropriate for some designated assets, particularly when it comes potential impacts on the setting of heritage assets. There is an embedded notion (especially amongst developers) that setting = intervisibility, which can often muddy the waters when undertaking a valid impact assessment. E.g if the significance of an asset is predominantly derived from its archaeological importance, and a solar farm 500m away won't impact on that, then whether it can be seen or not from the asset is largely irrelevant. Likewise, a wind turbine may be visible from more than 1km distance from an asset where visibility will impact on the significance of an asset e.g. views to and from a designed landscape associated with a historic house etc. 

I also note that they have excluded World Heritage Sites, but without a buffer. That won't work with the Stonehenge and Avebury WHS for starters, especially as some lines of site (that view of a wind turbine could potentially sit within), such as those aligned on the summer and winter solstices, are enshrined as direct contributors to the Site's Outstanding Universal Values.

 I think this is step in the right direction to undermine some of the outdated and uninformed arguments against renewable energy development, but the historic environment aspects will need some more nuanced thinking - in my opinion there does need to be some wider discussions regarding the perceived impacts of renewable energy development impacts within the planning system (both local and national) imho, as it can be a barrier to accepting planning applications in some cases.
column5:
friends of the earth, in collaboration with the university of exeter, has produced a study identifying land in england suitable for onshore renewable energy, supported by an interactive map. while the exclusion of aonbs, national parks, and prime agricultural land is commendable, i find the use of a 1km buffer around designated heritage assets to be arbitrary and not always effective in addressing the potential impacts on the historic environment.

the approach oversimplifies the relationship between heritage assets and their settings. setting does not equate solely to intervisibility. for example, a solar farm 500m from an asset primarily valued for its archaeological significance may not impact it even if visible. conversely, a wind turbine over 1km away could significantly affect the setting of a designed landscape associated with a historic house.

similarly, the exclusion of world heritage sites without a buffer is inadequate, particularly for sites like stonehenge and avebury, where visual alignments, such as those tied to solstices, directly contribute to their outstanding universal values.

while this initiative is a positive step toward countering outdated arguments against renewable energy, the treatment of the historic environment requires more nuanced consideration. broader discussions are needed at both local and national levels to address how perceived impacts on heritage influence renewable energy planning decisions, as these concerns often become barriers to approving applications.

column3:
Windkraft in Deutschland erlebt zurzeit vor allem eines: Gegenwind. Anwohner f√ºrchten Schlagschatten und Schallemissionen. Dass Angst und Empirie nicht zwingend beieinanderliegen m√ºssen, zeigt der Umstand, dass die Ablehnung von Neuanlagen dort am h√∂chsten ist, wo pers√∂nliche Erfahrung mit Windkraft praktisch nicht existiert. Das kennen wir auch aus anderen politischen Debatten.

Eine technische L√∂sung im Kleinformat scheint jetzt die spanische Firma gefunden zu haben. Das Unternehmen stellt Windkraftanlagen ohne Rotorbl√§tter her und kommt damit dem metaphorischen Windspargel n√§her als zuvor. ‚ÄûEingefangen‚Äú wird die Energie durch das Schwingen des Mastk√∂rpers im Wind statt durch die Rotation von Bl√§ttern. Durch das Ausnutzen der Ver√§nderung der Polarisation des Festk√∂rpers bei elastischer Verformung - dem sogenannten peizoelektrischen Effekt ‚Äì wird die Energie schlie√ülich gewonnen.

Die rotorlosen Anlagen sind kosteng√ºnstig und wartungsarm, Schallemissionen und Schattenwurf werden auf ein absolutes Minimum reduziert. Mehrere der Anlagen mit einer H√∂he von knapp drei Metern sollen den Strombedarf eines Haushalts decken k√∂nnen. Allerdings k√∂nnen sie bislang nicht gro√ü skaliert werden. Damit sind die Anlagen eher f√ºr die dezentrale Energiegewinnung √§hnlich einer hauseigenen Photovoltaikanlage geeignet.

Ein bisschen hilfreicher ist da die Idee des ebenfalls spanischen Windbauers Iberdrola. Zusammen mit Konsortialpartnern will das Unternehmen vor Norwegens K√ºste schwimmende Offshore-Windkraftanlagen errichten. Durch das ankernde und halbtauchende Fundament k√∂nnen Kosten eingespart und Eingriffe in das maritime √ñkosystem reduziert werden ‚Äì bei gleichzeitiger Gewinnung gro√üer Mengen Energie.

Weiterf√ºhrende Artikel: energate, Fachagentur Windenergie an Land, Vortex Bladeless



Konflikt der Woche: Green Deal unter Druck
Mit dem sogenannten Green Deal will die Europ√§ische Kommission im Rahmen von 50 Ma√ünahmen die Europ√§ische Union bis 2050 dekarbonisieren. Daf√ºr sollen billionenschwere Investitionen angeschoben werden, von denen die Privatwirtschaft die H√§lfte aufwenden soll. Doch die steuert dank Corona gerade hart auf eine Rezession zu.

Die rechtskonservative ECR-Fraktion im EU-Parlament forderte die europ√§ischen Pr√§sidenten deshalb diese Woche dazu auf, alle Vorhaben rund um den Green Deal auf unbestimmte Zeit auszusetzen. Noch wiedersetzt sich die EU-Spitze verbal. In Sachen Biodiversit√§t hat die EU-Kommission jedoch schon gehandelt und mit der Biodiversit√§tsstrategie einen wichtigen Baustein des Green Deal auf Eis gelegt. Ebenso hat sie ein Konsultationsverfahren f√ºr Unionsb√ºrgerinnen und -b√ºrger gestartet, um in Erfahrung zu bringen, ob diese die versch√§rften Klimaziele √ºberhaupt noch wollen.

Dahingegen scheint die Idee von ‚ÄûGreen Finance‚Äú bereits zu wirken. Gro√üanleger beginnen, Klimarisikomanagement strategisch anzugehen. So hat Barclays, gr√∂√üter Finanzierer der fossilen Energietr√§ger in der EU, angek√ºndigt, bis 2050 zu einer ‚ÄûNetto-Null-Bank‚Äú zu werden und alle Finanzierungsaktivit√§ten mit dem Pariser Klimaschutzabkommen in Einklang bringen zu wollen ‚Äì eine Entscheidung, die vor allem auf Druck institutioneller Investoren gefallen ist. Die Ver√∂ffentlichung f√§llt zusammen mit dem gegenw√§rtigen Schock auf den √ñlm√§rkten.

Weiterf√ºhrende Artikel: Barclays, Europ√§ische Kommission, Guardian, Finanzen.net



Nachricht der Woche: Happy Birthday, EEG!
Diese Woche j√§hrt sich das Inkrafttreten des Erneuerbare-Energien-Gesetzes (EEG) zum 20. Mal. Mit dem Jubil√§um f√§llt die Meldung zusammen, dass im letzten Quartal erstmals 52 Prozent des in Deutschland hergestellten Stroms aus Erneuerbaren Energiequellen stammte. Auch wenn ein einmaliger Effekt durch Corona miteinkalkuliert werden muss: Im vergangenen Jahr lag die Quote immer noch bei 46 Prozent. Es l√§sst sich also konstatieren, dass die Erneuerbaren den Markt wirklich durchdrungen haben.

Das ist auch Verdienst des EEG. Als es 2000 von der rot-gr√ºnen Regierung eingef√ºhrt wurde, sorgte das EEG f√ºr eine kostendeckende Verg√ºtung und privilegierten Netzzugang f√ºr Erneuerbare Energien und schuf damit die Rahmenbedingungen f√ºr Investitionen, die den technologischen Fortschritt befeuerten und Kosten rasant fallen lie√ü.

Es folgten sieben Jahr Solarboom. Zwischenzeitlich besch√§ftigte die Solarbranche in Deutschland 100.000 Arbeitnehmer und errichtete in den Jahren 2010 bis 2012 mehr solare Kapazit√§t als in den darauffolgenden sieben. Weil ab 2012 harte politische Einschnitte durch die schwarz-gelbe Regierung folgten und der Markt dem hohen Wettbewerbsdruck der chinesischen Produktion nicht Stand hielt, brach die Branche zusammen. Derzeit hat sich die Besch√§ftigtenzahl wieder bei rund 30.000 stabilisiert. Die gesunkenen Kosten f√ºhren dazu, dass wieder mehr gebaut wird. Die ausgeschriebenen Kapazit√§ten innerhalb des novellierten EEGs werden voll ausgesch√∂pft. Inzwischen entstehen auch Solarparks ohne F√∂rderung. Weil die Bundesregierung jedoch den selbst geschaffenen F√∂rderdeckel von 52 GW installierter Kapazit√§t entgegen des Willens praktisch aller Beteiligter nicht beseitigen will, k√∂nnte der derzeitige Boom schon im August abrupt ein Ende finden.

Selbiges passiert gerade bei der Windkraft. Das dem EEG seit der Novelle von 2016/2017 zugrundeliegende Ausschreibungsmodell f√ºhrt ‚Äì gepaart mit Genehmigungsstau, fehlender Kommunikation und Gegenwind durch den Wirtschaftsfl√ºgel der CDU ‚Äì zu einem Dahinsiechen des Ausbaus. Deutsche Windkraftbauer haben sich l√§ngst umorientiert und bieten ihre Produkte vermehrt auf dem Weltmarkt an. Auch deshalb ist der Branche die Krise der Solarwirtschaft bisher erspart geblieben.

Ein kommunikatives Grundproblem des EEG bleibt, dass die Umlage steigt, je h√∂her die Einspeisung der Erneuerbaren ist. Auf Grund dieses Paradoxes haben viele B√ºrger das Gef√ºhl, dass die Erneuerbaren Preistreiber seien. Das Gegenteil ist der Fall: Solar ist heute die g√ºnstigste Form der Energiegewinnung.

Das EEG ist effizient. Aber es wird Zeit, dass die Rahmenbedingungen wieder auf den Ausbau zugeschnitten werden und die Energiewende wieder durch Politiker gemacht wird, die sich nicht auf Kosten des EEGs profilieren wollen, sondern mit ihm ‚Äì zum Beispiel √ºber eine Teilhabe von benachbarten Gemeinden an Windkraftprojekten.

wind power in germany is currently facing backlash. residents fear noise and shadow flicker, despite these concerns being strongest where wind power is least experienced. innovative solutions like bladeless turbines, utilizing the piezoelectric effect, offer low-maintenance, quiet alternatives, but they‚Äôre suited only for small-scale use, like home energy.

iberdrola's floating offshore farms near norway are more impactful, reducing ecosystem disruption while producing large-scale energy.

the green deal aims to decarbonize the eu by 2050 but faces political and financial pushback, risking delays or halts in biodiversity efforts. green finance progresses, with banks like barclays committing to net-zero goals.

germany's eeg, pivotal for renewable growth, celebrates 20 years but needs reform. it‚Äôs time for policies to accelerate wind and solar expansion, ensure fair cost distribution, and incentivize community involvement to sustain momentum.

Energy Island Bornholm: A Pioneering Project with a Global Vision
Experts from all over the world are currently focusing on the Danish Baltic Sea island of Bornholm. The island, with around 40,000 inhabitants, known as the "Sun Island," aims to not only supply all of Denmark with green electricity from powerful offshore wind farms starting in 2030, but also to send a significant portion of the generated power to Germany.

For news, background, and the ambitious vision of Energy Island Bornholm, read the current edition of the Energiek√ºste Newsletter RADAR: Link

Not a subscriber yet? Sign up easily and for free: Link

Photo: Frederik Mouritsen via Pixabay
column5:
all eyes are on the danish baltic sea island of bornholm, and for good reason. with a population of around 40,000, the 'sun island' is set to become a game-changer in green energy. starting in 2030, bornholm plans to harness the power of large-scale offshore wind farms, not just to supply all of denmark with renewable electricity, but also to export a significant portion of that power to germany.

the energy island concept represents an ambitious vision, one that will make bornholm a key player in europe‚Äôs transition to green energy. the project has drawn attention from experts worldwide, signaling its potential to shape the future of energy across borders.
column13: European cooperation and its importance to energy island projects.

column3:
üá™üá∫ The energy transition is not a German, but a European project ‚Äì and the Baltic Sea can be an important factor in its success.

üí¨ At the Baltic Energy Island Summit on the island of Bornholm, our 50Hertz CEO Stefan Kapferer discussed this very topic with Hanne Storm Edlefsen from Energinet and State Secretary Philipp Nimmermann: How can we better connect wind farms at sea, utilize wind power more efficiently and thus distribute as much green electricity as possible from the windy north to Central Europe? And how should the framework conditions be designed so that all sides benefit?

üí° With our Bornholm Energy Island project, we at 50Hertz are already well on the way with Energinet. Together, we are creating the world's first energy island with our hybrid interconnector and turning Bornholm into a hub for green electricity ‚Äì in the middle of the Baltic Sea. The wind energy from the connected offshore parks with a capacity of 3 GW will then be available to the markets of both countries.

ü§© The importance of offshore and energy islands is demonstrated not only by the presence of the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Climate Protection, but also by the Danish Energy Minister Lars Aagaard and other important stakeholders on site.
column5:
the energy transition is a european project, not just a german one, and the baltic sea could play a critical role in its success. at the baltic energy island summit on bornholm, 50hertz ceo stefan kapferer, alongside hanne storm edlefsen from energinet and state secretary philipp nimmermann, discussed key questions: how can we better connect offshore wind farms? how can we make wind energy more efficient and distribute as much green electricity as possible from the wind-rich north to central europe? and how do we create the right conditions so that everyone benefits?

at 50hertz, we are already making progress with our bornholm energy island project, in partnership with energinet. together, we are building the world's first energy island with our hybrid interconnector, transforming bornholm into a green energy hub in the baltic sea. the wind power from the connected offshore parks, with a total capacity of 3 gw, will be accessible to both countries' markets.

the significance of offshore wind and energy islands is underscored by the participation of key stakeholders, including the federal ministry for economic affairs and climate protection, danish energy minister lars aagaard, and others at the summit.
column13: European cooperation and its importance to energy island projects.

column3:
‚ÄúWe believe that bundling this infrastructure centrally will reduce the environmental impact... and bring significant cost advantages,‚Äù said Dr. Elmar Friedrich, COP‚Äôs Market Director for Germany. He highlighted the crucial role energy islands could play in advancing offshore wind development in Germany. These energy islands can serve as hubs for the storage and transmission of wind energy, provide a cost-efficient platform for producing green hydrogen, and act as a base for maintaining offshore wind farms.

Energy islands offer a transformative solution to streamline and optimize the infrastructure required for large-scale offshore wind projects. By centralizing key functions like storage, transmission, and maintenance, they can significantly reduce costs and environmental impact while ensuring that the energy generated is distributed effectively. As we move forward, energy islands could be a game-changer in Europe‚Äôs energy transition, especially in offshore wind markets like Germany
column5: copenhagen offshore partners believes that centralizing offshore wind infrastructure will lead to less environmental impact and significant cost advantages. dr. elmar friedrich, cop's germany market director, emphasizes the crucial role energy islands will play in the future of offshore wind energy in germany. these energy islands will act as hubs for the storage and transmission of wind energy, provide a cost-efficient platform for green hydrogen production, and serve as bases for the maintenance of offshore wind farms.

column3:
Green light for green Baltic Sea electricity: Yesterday, the energy and climate protection ministers of #Denmark and #Germany agreed on the completion of #BornholmEnergyIsland (BEI) and the respective connections to both countries. ü§ù

We at #50Hertz are excited to be able to realize this crucial project for electricity supply and #ClimateProtection together with our Danish TSO partner Energinet. Compared to the original plans, the capacity of the planned #offshore wind farms has been increased to over three GW. As a result, Bornholm Energy Island will be able to supply almost eight million households with green electricity once operational (DK: 3.3 million / D: 4.5 million).

üëâ To bring the electricity from the sea to the land, we plan to lay 470 kilometers of direct current cables on the seabed and build an innovative electricity hub on Bornholm. Through international cooperation between EU partners, we are making further progress on the way to #100PercentBy2032 and #EnergySovereignty.
column5:
50hertz transmission gmbh supports the completion of bornholm energy island (bei) and its connections to both denmark and germany. this project, which is crucial for electricity supply and climate protection, will involve 50hertz and its danish transmission system operator (tso) partner energinet. compared to the initial plans, the capacity of the offshore wind farms planned for bei has been increased to over 3 gw, enabling bornholm energy island to supply up to nearly 8 million households with green electricity once operational (3.3 million in denmark, 4.5 million in germany). 

to bring the generated electricity ashore, 50hertz plans to lay 470 kilometers of direct current cables on the seabed and establish an innovative electricity hub on bornholm. through international cooperation with eu partners, 50hertz is taking significant steps toward achieving 100% renewable energy by 2032 and enhancing energy sovereignty.
column13: European cooperation and its importance to energy island projects.

column3:
Germany and Denmark's cooperation on the major offshore wind energy project has recently reached a new milestone: A new interconnector will enable the transport and exchange of offshore wind power between the two countries. This so-called Combined Grid Solution (CGS) is an innovation, as it creates the first electricity connection between two countries that not only transports offshore wind power to the land but also provides capacity for electricity trading. Federal Minister for Economic Affairs Peter Altmaier rightly calls the project a "European flagship project for cross-border cooperation in offshore wind energy."

However, it currently seems that the German-Danish wind energy collaboration could be somewhat one-sided. In the future, Denmark will have a significant amount of electricity to send to Germany, thanks to its very ambitious climate goals: Artificial energy islands are expected to form a 10-gigawatt wind power cluster in the coming years‚Äîinitially one in the North Sea and one in the Baltic Sea, with more to follow by 2030. Denmark will often not be able to use the generated wind power itself immediately, which is why the energy islands will convert the electricity into other forms like hydrogen through sector coupling facilities and also export it to other countries. The foundation for supplying Germany was laid with the recently inaugurated interconnector. Future transmission lines to the Netherlands and Poland are also planned.

Denmark‚Äôs climate projects serve as a clear role model

Such large-scale projects‚Äîafter all, the planned energy islands will be nothing less than the world‚Äôs largest offshore wind farm‚Äîshould, in my opinion, put the German government in a position where it has to explain itself. These projects make it clear that Denmark is far ahead of Germany in terms of energy transition. In fact, Denmark has always had a slight advantage in the fight against climate change, as the country embraced wind power in the early 90s. Since then, the Danes have quietly taken on a pioneering role. In 2017, renewable energies already covered 43% of the country's energy needs.

The climate package passed by the Danish government in June is another example of leadership: Whether it‚Äôs expanding renewable energies, promoting climate-friendly urban mobility, or transitioning from fossil heating systems to climate-friendly alternatives, Denmark is ahead of Germany in almost all areas. Although both countries have set similar goals‚Äîclimate neutrality by 2050‚Äîonly in Denmark does this goal currently seem truly achievable.

Climate protection vs. profitability: The German government needs to rethink

So what is holding Germany back? There is certainly no lack of good intentions, as evidenced by the recently passed economic stimulus package. It adjusted previous targets upwards, so, for example, offshore wind energy is now expected to produce 20 GW by 2030, instead of the previously planned 15 GW. There is also significant investment in areas such as the hydrogen industry, which enables the storage of surplus offshore wind energy.

Nonetheless, it must be noted that there is a lack of the courage needed to enable ambitious projects like the Danish energy islands. This is especially due to the fact that, in Germany, climate and economic policy are often seen as opposites. Instead of viewing the energy transition as the future economic driver, climate protection is mainly seen as an economic burden. There is little trust in the profitability of renewable energies. Meanwhile, the industry must not be burdened with too many restrictions or regulations, according to the prevailing opinion among the ruling parties. This ethos has been visible in recent months: The ‚Ç¨9 billion bailout of Lufthansa, for example, was not tied to any climate conditions, unlike the bailout of Air France in France.

With the economic stimulus package, the German government has indeed signaled its intention to take on a European leadership role in the fight against climate change. However, for this to succeed, it must reconsider its attitude towards climate protection and its economic viability‚Äîand take a cue from its northern neighbors, who are several steps‚Äîand several energy islands‚Äîahead.
column5:
i believe that denmark's ambitious energy transition and climate goals have positioned it ahead of germany in terms of renewable energy development, particularly in offshore wind energy. the new interconnector between denmark and germany, part of the combined grid solution (cgs), represents a significant step forward in cross-border cooperation. however, fischer sees the collaboration as potentially one-sided, with denmark set to supply much of its offshore wind power to germany due to its large-scale artificial energy islands, which will generate up to 10 gigawatts of wind power by 2030. denmark's ability to convert surplus energy into other forms like hydrogen for export adds to its leadership.
i criticize germany for lacking the ambition needed to undertake similar large-scale projects, especially as climate protection is often viewed as an economic burden rather than a driver of future economic growth. while germany has set goals for climate neutrality by 2050, fischer argues that only denmark appears to have a clear path to achieve this. fischer calls for the german government to rethink its approach to climate policy and profitability, using denmark as a model for success in renewable energy and the energy transition.
column13: European cooperation and its importance to energy island projects.

column3:
The autumn vacation in üá©üá∞ Denmark üá©üá∞ was a few days ago, and the rotor blades are still spinning in my mind. üòµüí´ü§©

I quickly researched at home, and wow: More than half of Denmark's electricity consumption is covered by wind power. By comparison, in Germany, it was exactly a quarter in 2022. And even in solar energy, despite (!) the seemingly constant cloud cover, our northern neighbor is making great strides: By August 2023, it accounted for 12% of public electricity generation, compared to 15.9% in Germany. And future plans go far beyond the small Scandinavian country.

In the next ten years, an offshore wind energy island will be built in the North Sea. Not 20, but more than 100 kilometers away from the coast, actually out at sea: with hundreds of wind turbines and a capacity of ten gigawatts. For comparison: Currently, all offshore wind farms in Germany generate just over seven gigawatts. The energy island will be the largest infrastructure project in Danish history. It aims to produce a significant amount of energy, including green hydrogen. Not only for domestic use but also for other countries.

Speaking of other countries. Today, Denmark is already supplying more electricity to the German power grid than any other country (including electricity from other Scandinavian nations), and this trend is increasing. Hats off to Denmark! Why did our neighboring country recognize the signs of the times so much earlier?
column5:
i am impressed by denmark‚Äôs leadership in wind energy and green energy production. the country now covers more than half of its electricity consumption with wind power, far ahead of germany, which only reached a quarter in 2022. in solar energy, despite the weather, denmark is also closing the gap, with a 12% contribution to public electricity generation in 2023, compared to germany's 15.9%. 

denmark‚Äôs future plans include the creation of a massive offshore wind energy island in the north sea, located over 100 kilometers from the coast. this energy island will have a capacity of ten gigawatts, far surpassing germany's current total offshore wind power capacity of seven gigawatts. the energy island will be the largest infrastructure project in danish history, producing significant amounts of energy, including green hydrogen, not only for denmark but also for other countries.

denmark is already supplying more electricity to germany than any other country, and this is expected to continue growing. i admire how denmark has recognized the future of energy transformation much earlier than germany.

column3:
Islands ‚Äì always places of longing ‚Äì are on the rise. Alongside the real ones, artificial ones are now being created. Denmark is currently deciding to build an energy island in the North Sea. Why? Because the North Sea is the only truly large and secure green power plant in Europe! Are these groundbreaking new ideas? Already during the oil crisis of the 1960s, visions for expanding Scharh√∂rn into a major energy hub for Hamburg emerged with the "Labskausdeal." At that time, the CEO of Salzgitter said, "Anyone thinking about investments in the steel industry today cannot ignore Scharh√∂rn."

For the other Nordic countries, the idea ultimately proved too visionary and costly, resulting in numerous energy-hungry companies from North Rhine-Westphalia relocating to Belgium and the Netherlands. For Hamburg, this led to a focus on the Elbe metropolis and HafenCity with numerous river deepening projects and a multi-billion euro dredging operation for German taxpayers without a real future perspective.

Now, Cuxhaven is positioning itself to seize the opportunity for the northern countries, with an island that aims to provide answers to the major questions of our time. We can look forward to the new, multifunctional ‚ÄúWatt'n Stoff Bundesinsel‚Äù (Federal Island).

for other nordic nations, the idea proved too visionary and expensive, which led many energy-intensive companies from north rhine-westphalia to relocate to belgium and the netherlands. for hamburg, this shift led to a focus on the elbe metropolis and hafencity with numerous river deepening projects, alongside a multi-billion-euro dredging operation funded by german taxpayers, yet lacking a genuine future outlook.

now, cuxhaven is positioning itself to capitalize on this opportunity for the northern countries with an island project that addresses the crucial challenges of today. we can eagerly anticipate the creation of the new, multifunctional "watt'n stoff bundesinsel" (federal island).

Men vi har brug for resultater her og nu. Og min pointe med dette skriv er, at vi ikke vinder klimakampen p√• flere hj√∏rnespark, hockeystave eller andre fortrampede sports-metaforer.

Dan J√∏rgensen tror p√• en energi-√∏ i Nords√∏en. Den best√•r af store dele teknologi, som vi dr√∏mmer om, men reelt ikke har. Jeg f√∏ler mig hensat til H C Andersens eventyret "Kejserens nye kl√¶der" og efterlyser flere af denne vigtige fort√¶llings plot-m√¶ssige hovedperson, -nemlig den lille dreng, der peger og siger, at Kejseren ikke har noget t√∏j p√•. column5:
we are chasing technological breakthroughs because we hope for solutions, and perhaps because we collectively realize that we must act on the un climate report and other scientific facts clearly indicating an urgent need for green transformation. 

the government's climate policy often includes the term "hockey stick," which is not meant as a nod to denmark's recent olympic hockey success but rather to describe delayed growth projections. however, we need results now, not hypothetical future growth. 

my point is that we won‚Äôt win the climate battle with vague promises or overused sports metaphors. dan j√∏rgensen believes in an energy island in the north sea, but it relies heavily on technology we dream of yet do not actually have. this reminds me of hans christian andersen‚Äôs tale, *the emperor‚Äôs new clothes*, and i am calling for more of the story‚Äôs essential figure‚Äîthe boy who points out the emperor‚Äôs lack of clothing.

we lack the power-to-x solution to prevent significant energy losses. additionally, the cost of expanding the energy grid to transport energy from the north sea would be as high as building the energy island itself, if it can even be built. this is in a country that, for three decades, couldn‚Äôt get ic4 trains to function.

column3:
Energi√∏ Nords√∏en har fra starten v√¶ret et vision√¶rt projekt, der kan bidrage til Europas gr√∏nne omstilling og forsyningssikkerhed. N√•r vi vil lave projekter, vi ikke har pr√∏vet f√∏r, s√• er der mange veje, snubletr√•de og sv√¶re valg at tr√¶ffe undervejs. Det g√¶lder ogs√• for energi√∏en. Derfor dette lidt lange skriv ‚Äì jeg h√•ber, du vil l√¶se med, for s√• store projekter indeholder mere end en hurtig overskrift.

Man kan godt dr√∏mme om et fedt projekt. Det er sv√¶rere at realisere det. Vi har derfor fra start p√• tv√¶rs af Folketingets partier v√¶ret enige i, at √∏konomien i projektet skal v√¶re ansvarlig. Vi skal ikke gennemf√∏re projektet for enhver pris ‚Äì og derfor meldte jeg allerede sidste sommer ud, at vi vil √¶ndre projektet, s√• prisen kommer ned. Sidste sommer l√∏d regningen for det oprindelige projekt p√• mere end 50 mia. kr. for statskassen. Det har aldrig v√¶ret den politiske intension. 
 
En stor del af form√•let med energi√∏en er at sende str√∏mmen til andre lande, og vi har derfor arbejdet sammen med Belgien. Danmark f√•r d√¶kket vores behov fra andre projekter, og derfor m√• danske skatteborgere ikke h√¶nge p√• en urimelig stor del af regningen, der ikke modsvares af gevinster for Danmark og danskerne. 

Det har vi diskuteret med Belgien helt op til det belgiske parlamentsvalg inden sommerferien, og vi har ikke kunnet finde en vej sammen, der var fornuftig og acceptabel for Danmark. Hvis en ny belgisk regering (n√•r en s√•dan er p√• plads‚Ä¶.) p√• et tidspunkt banker p√• vores d√∏r og er med p√• en mere balanceret fordeling af projektets omkostninger og gevinster, s√• er vores d√∏r selvf√∏lgelig √•ben. Det m√• ske p√• belgisk initiativ.
 
Vi har derfor ogs√• arbejdet p√• andre muligheder. Og det er meget positivt, at is√¶r Tyskland viser stor interesse for at blive tilkoblet energi√∏en. Vi er s√• langt i dialogen med Tyskland, at vi prioriterer vores indsats for at realisere projektet i retning af et samarbejde med Tyskland ‚Äì s√• energi√∏en f√•r et elkabel til Danmark og et til Tyskland. 

N√•r vi har brugt tid p√• at √¶ndre i projektet, s√• bliver tidspunktet for en mulig realisering skubbet ud i tid. Det kommer n√¶ppe bag p√• nogen. S√•dan er virkeligheden. Og vi bliver n√∏dt til at lytte til tyskerne om hvad de har af behov og √∏nsker til kapacitet, tidsplan osv. Man kan jo se tyskerne som en kunde, der √∏nsker at k√∏be sig ind i et gr√∏nt projekt, og det er selvsagt den tyske eftersp√∏rgsel efter str√∏mmen og mulighed for at udbygge deres el-infrastruktur, der vil blive udslagsgivende for, hvorn√•r projektet kan realiseres.

column5:
the danish energy island in the north sea is a visionary project that can contribute significantly to europe‚Äôs green transition and energy security. however, implementing such an unprecedented project involves many challenges, financial risks, and difficult decisions. from the beginning, political consensus across the danish parliament has been that the project must be economically responsible. the initial cost of over 50 billion dkk for the state was never the intention, and adjustments to reduce the price were announced last summer.

a key purpose of the energy island is to export electricity to other countries. collaboration with belgium was pursued, but we could not agree on a cost-benefit distribution that was fair and acceptable to denmark. should a future belgian government propose a more balanced agreement, denmark remains open to discussions.

in the meantime, we have engaged with other partners, particularly germany, which has shown significant interest in connecting to the energy island. our dialogue with germany is advanced, and we are now prioritizing a partnership where the energy island will connect to both denmark and germany through electrical cables. germany‚Äôs needs, including capacity and timelines, will influence the project‚Äôs realization as they are essentially a customer investing in this green project.

revised plans and partnerships mean the timeline for the energy island‚Äôs completion will be extended. however, this new direction with germany could make the project more financially feasible for denmark. the next steps involve concrete planning to create a foundation for political decision-making, which is currently in progress.
column13: How to finance the energy islands?

Energi√∏ Bornholm: En god investering i Danmarks og Europas fremtid

I jule- og nyt√•rstiden, hvor f√¶llesskabet er i h√∏js√¶det, og hvor vi reflekterer over vores f√¶lles fremtid, er det v√¶rd at s√¶tte fokus p√• projekter, der r√¶kker ud over vores tid og skaber v√¶rdi for kommende generationer. Sammen med Troels Ranis, vicedirekt√∏r i DI Energi, har jeg derfor skrevet et debatindl√¶g i Jyllands-Posten om Energi√∏ Bornholm og projektets betydning for vores f√¶lles fremtid.

Vi har samlet vores perspektiver i tre bundlinjer for Energi√∏ Bornholm:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Klimam√¶ssigt: Projektet vil i sig selv fortr√¶nge 3 mio. tons CO2 om √•ret, men endnu vigtigere bane vejen for flere energi√∏er, der er afg√∏rende for den gr√∏nne omstilling i EU.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Industripolitisk: Bornholm vil som eksisterende √∏ v√¶re den ideelle testplatform for fremtidens energi√∏er. Det vil give danske virksomheder en innovationsm√¶ssig fordel i udviklingen af energi√∏-teknologier.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Sikkerhedspolitisk: Energi√∏ Bornholm vil med sin kombination af elhandelsforbindelse og store m√¶ngder gr√∏n energi v√¶re et vigtigt skridt mod at frig√∏re EU fra russisk energi. Som det er tilf√¶ldet med klimaeffekterne, er projektet som et af de st√∏rste klimaprojekter nogensinde betydningsfuldt i sig selv. Men den st√∏rste effekt ligger igen i, at projektet baner vejen for flere energi√∏er, som samlet set vil v√¶re afg√∏rende for, at Europa kan blive selvforsynende med energi.

Derudover argumenterer vi ogs√• for, at projektet har gode chancer for at v√¶re en god forretning for Danmark. De nuv√¶rende beregninger viser godt nok en negativ samfunds√∏konomi p√• 4 mia. kr., men det skyldes, at Energistyrelsens beregninger har sv√¶rt ved at medregne de mange gevinster, som projektet har p√• grund af sin innovative karakter.

energi√∏ bornholm is a critical investment in the future of denmark and europe, delivering long-term value across three essential areas: climate, industrial innovation, and security policy.

from a climate perspective, energi√∏ bornholm will directly displace 3 million tons of co‚ÇÇ annually and pave the way for additional energy islands. these islands are vital for achieving the eu‚Äôs green transition goals.

from an industrial standpoint, bornholm is an ideal test platform for future energy island technologies. as an existing island, it offers a unique opportunity for danish companies to develop and innovate energy island solutions, strengthening their competitive edge in this emerging field.

in terms of security policy, energi√∏ bornholm will combine electricity trading connections with large-scale green energy production, representing a major step toward reducing the eu‚Äôs dependency on russian energy. the project's true value lies not only in its immediate impact but also in its role as a precursor to more energy islands that will collectively contribute to europe‚Äôs energy self-sufficiency.

while current calculations show a 4 billion dkk economic deficit, these figures fail to account for the broader benefits of energi√∏ bornholm. the innovative nature of the project delivers significant advantages, including climate gains, enhanced technological leadership for denmark, and energy independence for europe. energi√∏ bornholm is not just a project for the present; it is a foundation for sustainable progress for future generations.

KONGELIG INTERESSE FOR ENERGI√ò BORNHOLM üëë‚ö°
Energi√∏ Bornholm er p√• mange m√•der et fascinerende projekt. Det var tydeligt, da H. M. Kongen og H. M. Dronningen kiggede forbi R√∏nne Gamle Elv√¶rk p√• deres √•rlige sommertogt, der blev indledt p√• Bornholm mandag den 19. august. 

Her blev kongeparret vist rundt i udstillingen om energi√∏er, der ud over at v√¶re et teknologisk kvantespring inden for energi fra havvind ogs√• er centrum for lokal og regional udvikling. Blandt andet er flere st√¶rke kr√¶fter g√•et sammen i fonden Baltic Energy Island for at g√∏re Bornholm til et europ√¶isk knudepunkt for test af gr√∏nne teknologier og systemer til gavn for den gr√∏nne omstilling. 

Det arbejde fik Deres Majest√¶ter ogs√• et interessant indblik i under dagens bes√∏g, hvor de blev vist rundt af direkt√∏r for Baltic Energy Island, S√∏ren M√∏ller Christensen, rektor for DTU, Anders Overgaard Bjarklev, og bestyrelsesformand for Baltic Energy Island og direkt√∏r for Bornholms Energi og Forsyning, Claus M. Andersen. 

Energi√∏ Bornholm er godt p√• vej p√• flere fronter: 
‚ö° Havbundsunders√∏gelser for havvindm√∏lleparkerne og kablerne er afsluttet. 
‚ö° Udbuddet af h√∏jsp√¶ndingsudstyr i samarbejde med vores tyske TSO-kollega 50Hertz Transmission GmbH er i gang. Det samme g√¶lder for kabler. 
‚ö° Projektet er blevet politisk godkendt og er optaget p√• EU-Kommissionens liste over ‚ÄùProjects of common European Interest‚Äù.
‚ö° Vi er i t√¶t dialog med Bornholms Regionskommune ‚Äì senest om lokalplanen for anl√¶gget p√• Bornholm. Lokalplanen forventes at blive godkendt i efter√•ret 2024. 
‚ö° Plan for Program Energi√∏ Bornholm er godkendt. Planen s√¶tter de overordnede rammer for energi√∏en ‚Äì hvor anl√¶g m√• ligge, hvordan projektet skal tage hensyn til dyr, milj√∏ og mennesker, hvor h√∏je havvindm√∏llerne maksimalt m√• v√¶re. 
‚ö° De ark√¶ologiske forunders√∏gelser blev afsluttet i for√•ret 2024. Bornholms Museum afventer en dato for de egentlige ark√¶ologiske udgravninger. Flere af de ark√¶ologiske fund kan ses i udstillingen p√• det gamle elv√¶rk.
column5:
energi√∏ bornholm is a groundbreaking project that represents a technological leap forward in offshore wind energy while also serving as a hub for local and regional development. the project has garnered significant attention, including from the danish royal family, who recently visited r√∏nne gamle elv√¶rk to learn about its potential.

energi√∏ bornholm is advancing on multiple fronts:

- seabed surveys for wind farms and cables have been completed.
- procurement processes for high-voltage equipment and cables are underway in collaboration with the german transmission system operator 50hertz transmission gmbh.
- the project has received political approval and has been included on the european commission‚Äôs list of ‚Äúprojects of common european interest.‚Äù
- there is ongoing coordination with bornholms regionskommune, including work on a local development plan for the facilities on bornholm, which is expected to be approved in autumn 2024.
- the program plan for energi√∏ bornholm, which defines the project‚Äôs overarching framework, including considerations for animals, the environment, and the local community, has been approved. the plan also outlines height restrictions for offshore wind turbines and placement guidelines for infrastructure.
- archaeological preliminary studies were completed in spring 2024, and further excavations are planned. some of the archaeological findings are already displayed at the exhibition in the old power station.

additionally, bornholm is positioning itself as a european hub for testing green technologies and systems through the efforts of the baltic energy island foundation. energi√∏ bornholm is central to advancing the green transition and exemplifies innovative and collaborative solutions for sustainable energy development.

column3:
D√∏d ved 1000 snit
Energi√∏en i Nords√∏en er blevet udskudt flere gange. Kontoret i Energistyrelsen er lukket, og man er stadig ikke i n√¶rheden af en rentabel l√∏sning. 

Derfor m√• energi√∏en i Nords√∏en siges at v√¶re d√∏d i sin oprindelige form, og her fire √•r senere er vi alts√• stadig ikke kommet nogen vegne.

I Kraka Economics klimaafdeling har vi siden 2021 analyseret forskellige forhold omkring blandt andet energi√∏en i Nords√∏en, og vi kom hurtigt frem til den konklusion, at projektet b√∏r droppes - af mange √•rsager. De samme √•rsager, som ministeren nu fremf√∏rer som argumenter for at udskyde energi√∏en i Nords√∏en, fx:  

- Energi√∏en kunne ikke leve op til det oprindelige krav om rentabilitet.

- Det har ikke v√¶ret muligt at blive enige om en rimelig fordeling af gevinster og omkostninger med et samarbejdsland.

- St√∏rstedelen af str√∏mmen skal sendes til udlandet, s√• derfor skal   skatteborgerne ikke h√¶nge p√• en urimelig regning.

Alle disse gode grunde til at droppe energi√∏en i Nords√∏en kan direkte overf√∏res til Energi√∏ Bornholm. Faktisk har denne energi√∏ et forventet st√∏ttebehov pr. GW p√• hele 10 mia. kr., og til sammenligning har energi√∏en i Nords√∏en "kun" st√∏ttebehov p√• med 5 mia. kr.  

Det er fuldst√¶ndig uforst√•eligt, at man arbejder videre med et projekt, der er dobbelt s√• dyrt, som et projekt, der droppes ‚Ä¶ fordi det er for dyrt.

Vi opfordrer derfor regeringen til at udnytte det aktuelle klarsyn og droppe Energi√∏ Bornholm.
column5:
the energy island project in the north sea is effectively dead in its original form. despite multiple delays, closure of relevant offices, and a lack of progress, the project remains far from being financially viable. at kraka economics, our climate department has been analyzing various aspects of the north sea energy island since 2021, and we concluded early on that the project should be abandoned for several reasons. these reasons align with the minister's current arguments for postponing the project, including the inability to meet profitability targets, unresolved issues over fair distribution of costs and benefits with collaborating countries, and the fact that most of the electricity generated would be exported, meaning taxpayers should not bear an unreasonable financial burden.

these same concerns are applicable to the bornholm energy island. in fact, this project is expected to require 10 billion dkk per gigawatt in subsidies, compared to the north sea energy island's 5 billion dkk per gigawatt. it is incomprehensible to continue pursuing a project that is twice as expensive as one already deemed too costly to proceed with. we strongly urge the government to recognize the current clarity and cancel the bornholm energy island project.

column3:
PLAN FOR PROGRAM ENERGI√ò BORNHOLM I H√òRING

Titlen "Plan for Program Energi√∏ Bornholm" er nok ikke lige det, der f√•r pulsen op hos de fleste af jer. Men under den t√∏rre titel gemmer sig faktisk en vigtig milep√¶l p√• vej mod at g√∏re hashtag#Energi√∏ Bornholm til virkelighed. Planen s√¶tter den overordnede ramme for, hvordan projektet etableres og hvordan det potentielt p√•virker milj√∏et. 

Nu sender Danish Energy Agency planen og milj√∏vurderingen i 2. offentlighedsfase frem til 1. december. Planen forventes vedtaget i starten af n√¶ste √•r. Under planen etableres tre projekter: 
1) Havvindm√∏lleparkerne syd og vest for Bornholm.
2) Kabelforbindelsen til Tyskland, som etableres af vores tyske kollegaer fra 50Hertz Transmission GmbH. 
3) Og ikke mindst Energinets anl√¶g, som omfatter to omformerstationer, p√• henholdsvis Bornholm og Sj√¶lland og en 1,2 GW j√¶vnstr√∏msforbindelse i mellem dem. 

hashtag#√òbisserne har bist√•et Energistyrelsen med udarbejdelse af den milj√∏vurdering, der f√∏lger planen for Energi√∏ Bornholm p√• havet og p√• land. Milj√∏vurderingen beskriver - p√• overordnet niveau - de milj√∏m√¶ssige konsekvenser, det kan have at etablere en fuld udbygget Energi√∏ Bornholm. Milj√∏vurderingen giver alts√• et billede af, hvordan vi kan tage bedst muligt hensyn, n√•r vi bygger energi√∏en.

Alle interesserede kan finde h√∏ringsmaterialet og sende et h√∏ringssvar frem til 1. december. L√¶s mere p√• Energistyrelsens hjemmeside: www.

the "plan for program energy island bornholm" represents a crucial milestone in making energy island bornholm a reality. this plan establishes the overall framework for the project's implementation and its potential environmental impacts. the danish energy agency is now putting this plan and its environmental assessment into a second public consultation phase until december 1st, with the plan expected to be adopted in early next year.

the project consists of three main components:
1. offshore wind farms south and west of bornholm
2. a cable connection to germany, being established by our german colleagues at 50hertz transmission gmbh
3. energinet's facilities, which include two converter stations (one on bornholm and one on zealand) and a 1.2 gw dc connection between them

the √∏bisserne team has assisted the danish energy agency in preparing the environmental impact assessment that accompanies the energy island bornholm plan, both for marine and land-based aspects. this assessment outlines the environmental consequences of a fully developed energy island bornholm at a general level, helping us understand how to best consider environmental factors during construction.

all interested parties can access the consultation materials and submit responses until december 1st through the danish energy agency's website.
