column3:
Energi√∏ Bornholm er en √∏konomisk katastrofe.
 
Energi√∏ Bornholm blev oprindeligt besluttet med en foruds√¶tning om rentabilitet, men har siden vist sig at have et samfunds√∏konomisk underskud og kr√¶ve hele 31,5 mia. kr. i statsst√∏tte.
 
I Kraka Economics g√•r vi i h√∏j grad ind for en storstilet udbygning af havvind i Danmark, men det skal ske p√• kommercielle vilk√•r uden statsst√∏tte, som vi fx ser med det igangv√¶rende udbud af 6 GW havvind.
 
Det g√∏r sig ikke mindst g√¶ldende, fordi klart st√∏rstedelen af str√∏mmen skal sendes til Tyskland, hvorfor danske skatteborgere reelt ender med at statsst√∏tte gr√∏n str√∏m i Tyskland.
 
Energi√∏en bidrager selvf√∏lgelig med mere end vindm√∏ller, da projektet ogs√• indeholder en kabelforbindelse mellem Danmark og Tyskland, der forbedrer forsyningssikkerheden. Hvis man derfor insisterer p√• at bygge et kabel, er en omvej over Bornholm dog n√¶ppe den billigste m√•de at forbinde Sj√¶lland med Tyskland, og n√•r anden havvind kan opf√∏res st√∏ttefrit, b√∏r det v√¶re muligt at f√• b√•de kabel og havvind betydeligt billigere.
 
Opfordringen herfra er derfor klar: Drop det √∏konomiske vanvidsprojekt Energi√∏ Bornholm
column5:
energi√∏ bornholm is an economic disaster. the project was initially planned under the assumption of profitability but has since revealed a societal economic deficit and requires 31.5 billion dkk in state subsidies.

we strongly support large-scale offshore wind expansion in denmark, but it must be done on commercial terms without state subsidies, as demonstrated by the current 6 gw offshore wind tender. this is especially important because the majority of the electricity produced by energi√∏ bornholm will be sent to germany, effectively making danish taxpayers subsidize green electricity for germany.

while energi√∏ bornholm does offer additional benefits, such as a cable connection between denmark and germany to improve energy security, routing this connection through bornholm is unlikely to be the most cost-effective solution. furthermore, since other offshore wind projects can be developed subsidy-free, it should be possible to achieve both the cable connection and offshore wind generation at a much lower cost.

the recommendation from us is unequivocal: abandon the financially unsustainable energi√∏ bornholm project.

column3:
Det lyder som en rigtig god ide at komme i en t√¶ttere dialog med Tyskland om realisering af Energi√∏ Nords√∏en. 

Tyskland vil under alle omst√¶ndigheder v√¶re en af de st√∏rste aftagere af gr√∏n str√∏m, s√• det giver rigtig god mening at intensivere samarbejdet. Ydermere er der allerede et godt samarbejde om Energi√∏ Bornholm, hvorfor det er oplagt at drage yderligere nytte af disse erfaringer.

Det er selvf√∏lgelig √¶rgerligt, at det skyder hele tidsplanen med op til tre √•r. 

Vi eftersp√∏rger hastighed i den gr√∏nne omstilling og rettidig omhu. N√•r tidsplanerne hele tiden forskubber sig, kan det v√¶re sv√¶rt at planl√¶gge produktionen af de vindm√∏ller, kabler og transformerstationer, som skal v√¶re en del af en energi√∏. 

Det kr√¶ver meget stor fleksibilitet i industrien. 

DERFOR: vigtigt, at ambitionen fastholdes = at Nords√∏en skal v√¶re en ‚Äùpower hub‚Äù for hele Europa. Og det kr√¶ver en massiv udbygning, hvor energi√∏er er en del af l√∏sningen.
column5:
establishing a closer dialogue with germany about the realization of the north sea energy island is an excellent idea. germany will inevitably be one of the largest purchasers of green electricity, so intensifying cooperation makes perfect sense. the existing cooperation on the bornholm energy island has already yielded valuable experiences, and using those lessons for additional projects is an obvious next step.

unfortunately, this new approach may delay the overall timeline by up to three years. speed in the green transition and timely caution are vital objectives. shifting deadlines complicate the planning of wind turbines, cables, and transformer stations that must form part of any energy island. this situation demands a very high degree of flexibility from the industry.

for this reason, maintaining the ambition for the north sea to serve as a power hub for all of europe is absolutely crucial. achieving that vision requires a massive scale-up of infrastructure, and energy islands are a key component of the solution.
column13: European cooperation and its importance to energy island projects.

kraka economics supports the delay of the energi√∏ bornholm tender because politicians urgently need time to reconsider. the danish energy agency is reportedly working on updated calculations, which we believe will show an even worse economic outlook for the project due to rising infrastructure costs. 

additionally, we expect the 6 gw offshore wind tender to underperform, failing to provide the necessary funds to support energi√∏ bornholm's state subsidies.

with a potential funding gap that could grow by 8-10 billion dkk, and a diminishing pool of financing from other offshore wind projects, politicians will face a significant financial challenge.

it is a wise decision to pause the tender, giving politicians the opportunity to take responsibility and rethink whether to continue with a project that could cost danish taxpayers billions. however, it is crucial that politicians do not delay too long, as energinet needs to sign contracts with suppliers for cables and transformer stations early in the new year. once these contracts are signed, canceling the project would come at a much higher cost, as it would not be cheap to tear up these agreements.

Det er en v√¶sentlig, retlig mangel, konkluderer n√¶vnet: Planl√¶gning inden for kystn√¶rhedszonen skal have en s√¶rlig planl√¶gningsm√¶ssig eller funktionel begrundelse - ikke mindst n√•r der planl√¶gges for arealer p√• land, der foruds√¶tter inddragelse af s√∏territoriet.

column5:
the municipality has failed to provide adequate justification for establishing a new energy island at masned√∏ harbor. when planning within the coastal proximity zone, there must be specific planning or functional reasons - especially for projects on land that require incorporating sea territory. 

the municipality incorrectly assumed that new land areas reclaimed from sea territory would become part of the coastal urban zone rather than the coastal proximity zone. this is a significant legal deficiency.

for development in coastal proximity zones, clear justification is required under section 5b of the planning act. the municipality has not sufficiently explained why a solar cell facility must be located near the coast or in connection with the existing harbor. incorporation of sea territory can only be permitted in very special cases.

i am therefore overturning the local development plan based on these significant legal deficiencies. the supplementary plan 19 to the municipal plan and local plan h 17.03.01, which would transfer the new energy island to urban zone, cannot proceed without proper coastal zone justification.

column5:
the global supply of copper and aluminum, critical for the "energy island" project, is severely limited. currently, 90% of copper mines are operated by seven companies, four of which have significant chinese ownership. by 2030, copper demand‚Äîparticularly for cabling‚Äîwill exceed supply by 30%, even with accelerated mining efforts. aluminum faces an even worse production deficit and is at the top of the eu's list of critical resources under china's dominance. 

this scarcity will result in supply lines (made from aluminum) becoming significantly more expensive than the production equipment and energy island infrastructure itself. additionally, energy transmission losses over long distances are a major issue. 

from a logical standpoint, energy should be produced near its point of consumption. floating nuclear power plants offer a much more flexible and practical solution than the energy islands. they avoid the supply chain and energy loss issues while providing a decentralized energy production model that aligns better with actual needs.

column3:
More than 60 participants from 12 countries gathered at the European Parliament for the launch of the Energy Island Forum‚Äôs first roadmap, ‚ÄúMAKING ENERGY ISLANDS A SUCCESS.‚Äù 

This event marks a significant milestone in the journey toward developing Europe‚Äôs first energy islands. The roadmap outlines the critical steps to realize these islands by 2030 and lays the groundwork for long-term innovation leading up to 2050.

The roadmap was presented by Energy Island Forum Chairman Professor Nicolaos A. Cutululis and co-hosted by MEPs Niels Fuglsang (Denmark) and Borys Budka (Poland), Chair of the ITRE Committee, who are championing this initiative to accelerate Europe‚Äôs green transition.

It showcased the collaboration and determination required to make energy islands a cornerstone of Europe‚Äôs green transition.

The roadmap was discussed and commented on by key figures including Joachim Balke, Head of Unit for Infrastructure and Regional Cooperation, DG Energy, European Commission; James Matthys-Donnadieu, Chief Officer Customers, Markets and System, Elia; Dirk Van Hertem, Professor, KU Leuven; Ulrik Stridb√¶k, Vice President, Head of Regulatory Affairs, √òrsted; and Hessel de Jong, COO, Copenhagen Energy Islands (CIP).

Key take aways:
- Niels Fuglsang emphasized that energy islands are central to the EU's priorities, contributing to the fight against climate change, enhancing security through energy independence, and boosting European competitiveness.
- The panel highlighted the importance of completing the first energy islands by 2030 or shortly after. These initial projects will serve as stepping stones for future innovations in energy islands. To achieve this, we must address financial risks and find ways to finance the necessary grid infrastructure.
- While we may face technological challenges and significant investments, the greater danger lies in inaction. Failing to combat climate change and allowing non-European countries to lead in technological advancements will leave us dependent on their achievements.
column5:
the launch of the energy island forum‚Äôs first roadmap, ‚Äúmaking energy islands a success,‚Äù at the european parliament marks a pivotal moment in the development of europe‚Äôs first energy islands. with over 60 participants from 12 countries, the event demonstrated the international commitment to making energy islands a cornerstone of europe‚Äôs green transition.

the roadmap, presented by energy island forum chairman professor nicolaos a. cutululis and co-hosted by meps niels fuglsang and borys budka, outlines the necessary steps to complete the first energy islands by 2030 and sets the stage for long-term innovation through 2050. key stakeholders, including the european commission, √∏rsted, and copenhagen energy islands, contributed insights.

key takeaways from the event include:
1. energy islands are essential to the eu‚Äôs goals, addressing climate change, enhancing energy security, and boosting european competitiveness.
2. the completion of the first energy islands by 2030 is critical. these projects will drive the innovations needed for future developments. however, financial risks and grid infrastructure funding must be addressed to ensure success.
3. technological challenges and high investments are expected, but the greater risk is inaction. failing to act on climate change and allowing non-european nations to dominate technological advancements will leave europe dependent on external achievements.

baltic energy island is committed to advancing this vision and ensuring energy islands play a transformative role in europe‚Äôs energy future.

column4: Brian Vad Mathiesen, professor of energy planning at Aalborg University
column5:
the energy island project at bornholm is complex. i have repeatedly pointed out that quadrupling renewable energy (re) on land and expanding it at sea goes far beyond what denmark can technically handle. by 2030, denmark will be nearly self-sufficient in electricity. 

we need to continue advancing re goals and shift towards a consumption-driven system, where new electricity demands will drive investments in the cheapest re sources. the economic sustainability of the energy island needs to be tested, but production must align with demand. it's crucial to integrate technologies like power-to-x and data centers to absorb excess production and reduce the use of fossil fuels in high-emission sectors.

the energy island at bornholm is not just about denmark's energy security, but also about enhancing europe's collective energy security. the criticism of the project's economics is valid, but it's important to also consider alternative solutions, such as connecting the island to networks in sweden or poland to reduce costs.

despite challenges, it is likely that the energy island project will be realized, though possibly with adjustments or delays. the recent cancellation of the north sea project is a positive sign that projects are being adjusted to economic realities instead of being pushed forward regardless of cost. it's good to scrutinize the economics, but this doesn't change the fact that profitable and subsidy-free offshore wind farms exist in the baltic sea. the complex economics of the bornholm energy island are more related to the design of the park than to the wind turbines themselves.

energy security, cost-effectiveness, timing, and providing green energy for new consumption in the baltic sea region are the key factors to move forward.

column5:
there appears to be a challenge here. while i agree that the focus of the decision should be on the justification, especially since this is not a harbor facility as such, i believe there's a misunderstanding in the ruling regarding the zoning status of areas emerging from territorial waters, whether naturally or through land reclamation.

the appeals board's corrected decision from 2020 regarding faxe municipality's final adoption of municipal plan supplement no. 13 and local plan no. 300-46 clearly states that planning for land areas that will emerge after filling, with necessary permits from the coastal authority, is legally valid. there can be a planning-related need to adopt necessary plans for these areas' use before filling is permitted and implemented. this allows the overall planning purpose to undergo public debate and potential adjustments before specific decisions about land reclamation are made.

this approach is standard practice in other contexts where planning occurs before specific decisions about exemptions from nature protection laws and similar matters. it's also legal to plan for areas expected to emerge naturally, though such planning cannot take effect for citizens and developers until the areas actually become land. if these areas are later restored to water, the plan would no longer apply.

it's difficult to imagine that a reclaimed area within an existing local plan should be treated as rural zone if it's already planned as urban zone and would thus become part of the coastal urban zone upon reclamation. however, i might be misunderstanding this myself, so i agree with sune porse carlsen that proper guidance on this matter would be beneficial.

DK importerer ogs√• str√∏m stil fra andre lande, som satser p√• p√•lidelige gr√∏nne energikilder.
Det vil I ikke i DK, men tiden er m√•ske til HELT at skifte politik p√• dette omr√•de.
Hvis alle andre lande gjorde det samme som DK og D p√• energimor√•det, s√• skulle alt s√¶ttes i st√• i de perioder, hvor solen ikke skinner og hvor det ikke bl√¶ser.

column5:
the decision to halt certain aspects of the energy island project is a sensible one given the current geopolitical and energy landscape. forming a new government in belgium can take a very long time, and in germany, with its deeply flawed energy policies, a governmental shift is necessary. the current danish vice chancellor appears disconnected from reality. germany is europe‚Äôs largest importer of electricity, primarily relying on french nuclear power, while denmark also imports electricity from countries with reliable green energy sources. 

denmark‚Äôs current approach to projects like the energy island, which heavily relies on intermittent renewable sources such as wind and solar, is unsustainable. if all countries adopted similar policies, energy production would halt during periods without sunlight or wind. investing in battery capacity as an alternative for projects like the energy island would be prohibitively expensive, costing approximately denmark's entire annual gdp (2,800 billion dkk). 

despite these challenges, organizations like green power denmark remain adamantly opposed to nuclear power. this resistance perpetuates the shortcomings of initiatives like the energy island and similar projects. the continuation of these flawed policies is likely until a blue (conservative) government is in place.

column3:
Jeg er meget enig. Vi skal have forbruget op, s√• der er grund til at ops√¶tte mere VE produktion. Her kan PtX v√¶re et godt redskab, til trods for teknologiens relativt lave modenhedsstadie, fordi PtX b√•de er et √∏get forbrug, men ogs√• fordi produkterne fra PtX kan hj√¶lpe med at √∏ge vores forsyningssikkerhed.

Jeg har et sp√∏rgsm√•l. Vi priss√¶tter CO2 udledning, feks gennem EU ETS, hvilket underst√∏tter omstillingen. Har vi tilsvarende prissat forsyningssikkerhed? Og kan en priss√¶tning af forsyningssikkerhed v√¶re med til at √¶ndre p√• de samfunds√∏konomiske beregninger?

Jeg mener, i 2022 s√• vi en voldsom stigning i energipriserne fordi der opstod tvivl om forsyningssikkerheden. Stigende energipriser leder til stigende produktpriser, og vi endte med en meget h√∏j inflation. P√• bagsiden af inflation er der risiko for en periode med deflation og derved et fattigere samfund. 
Jeg siger ikke, at EU skal v√¶re en √∏, rent energim√¶ssigt, men jeg t√¶nker at det har en omkostning for EU at v√¶re mere eller mindre afh√¶ngige af import af energi, og at det b√∏r spille ind i beregningerne, n√•r man ser p√• rentabiliteten af at lave mere VE produktion b√•de til DK og som tv√¶rnationale projekter
column5:
i strongly agree that we need to increase energy consumption to justify the establishment of more renewable energy production. power-to-x (ptx) can be a useful tool in this regard, despite its relatively early stage of technological development, because ptx not only increases consumption but also produces products that can enhance our energy security.

i have a question: we price co2 emissions, for example through the eu emissions trading system (eu ets), which supports the transition to greener energy. but do we similarly price energy security? could pricing energy security help alter the socioeconomic calculations when assessing the profitability of further renewable energy projects, both within denmark and as cross-border initiatives?

i believe that in 2022, we saw a sharp rise in energy prices due to concerns about energy security. rising energy prices led to higher product prices, and we ended up with very high inflation. behind inflation, there is the risk of a period of deflation, which could result in a poorer society. 

i am not suggesting that the eu should become an energy island, but i do think there is a cost to the eu being more or less dependent on energy imports, and this factor should be considered when evaluating the profitability of expanding renewable energy production, both for denmark and for multinational projects.

yes, there is still a need for a well-connected grid in the north sea. the focus must be on the most important elements: wind power and seabed connections, specifically in the form of electrical cables and hydrogen pipelines. at energiens folkem√∏de in esbjerg, i had the opportunity to discuss these topics with industry colleagues. 

energinet is actively exploring an alternative solution to the original artificial island concept for energy island north sea. this new approach is less risky while still enabling the capture of significant offshore wind energy. 

as global electrification accelerates, a substantial increase in electricity production is essential. international connections, cross-border collaboration, and the integration of electricity and hydrogen are crucial for this transition. achieving climate goals requires a systemic transformation of our society through electrification and innovative technologies. this is the core purpose of the energy island projects, including energy island north sea.

Dette skift i fokus viser, at vi er p√• rette vej mod en teknisk og politisk velfunderet l√∏sning, ligesom det er tilf√¶ldet med Energi√∏ Bornholm, hvor Tyskland ogs√• er partner. Det √•bner ogs√• for potentialerne for at skabe synergier mellem de to √∏er.

Bl.a. omstillingen af vores samfund til b√¶redygtig gr√∏n str√∏m, sikringen af Danmarks deltagelse i udviklingen af nye PtX- og CCS-teknologier samt udviklingen af vores kritiske energiinfrastruktur for at reducere s√•rbarheden over for fremtidige geopolitiske konflikter.

i am excited about the recent news from climate and energy minister lars aagaard regarding the energy island project in the north sea. the discussion has now shifted from the question of foundation types‚Äîwhether steel platforms or an artificial island‚Äîto focusing on cooperation with our neighboring country, germany, on the transmission of energy from the north sea via an energy island solution.

this shift in focus demonstrates that we are on the right path toward a technically and politically well-grounded solution, much like the energy island project on bornholm, where germany is also a partner. this also opens up potential synergies between the two islands.

moving forward, we must continue working to solve some of the biggest challenges facing denmark and europe, including the transition of our societies to sustainable green energy, securing denmark‚Äôs participation in the development of new ptx and ccs technologies, and developing our critical energy infrastructure to reduce vulnerability to future geopolitical conflicts.

finally, i want to highlight that, despite the delay of the north sea energy island, lars aagaard points out that while we have been set back, we have not gone back to square one.

it is encouraging to see the shift in focus toward market collaborations rather than the technical debate about an enclosed island versus platforms, which are economically very similar (as demonstrated by data from energinet, referenced in zetland‚Äôs article). this shift is crucial because optimizing and financing the transmission infrastructure is key to the project‚Äôs economics and success.

as part of sweco‚Äôs advisory team, it has been a privilege to contribute to the preparatory work on the north sea energy island. it is promising if this work resumes, allowing us to harness the enormous energy potential of the north sea. this project presents a unique opportunity for both denmark and europe to strengthen the green transition and ensure a robust, sustainable energy infrastructure for the future.

i am excited to see how collaboration with germany can further advance the project and create synergies with other energy islands like bornholm, while we continue addressing the greatest technological challenges, including power-to-x (ptx) and carbon capture and storage (ccs), to secure our energy security in an increasingly complex geopolitical landscape.

i thought the fantasy islands were supposed to be much faster and cheaper than nuclear power. at least, that‚Äôs what dan j√∏rgensen said. perhaps he should spend less energy on vanity projects and more on honoring the commitment to "accelerate nuclear power" that he signed at cop28.  

there are more small modular reactors in operation than energy islands, yet nuclear power has been framed as technologically uncertain. the opposite is true. the swedes will likely establish their new nuclear power plants long before the social democrats‚Äô fantasy island becomes a reality.  

a system based on unstable energy sources is heavily reliant on international trade. the cost of such a system should include the expenses of creating these connections. energy island bornholm will be expensive and lead to societal losses, while the north sea energy island is entirely unprofitable and has been scrapped due to these connections. yet, these costs are not factored in.  

we await news about energy island bornholm with anticipation, though the outlook, based on current analyses, is bleak. it appears more costly to construct and may yield less revenue from offshore wind tenders to fund it. taxpayers should not bear the burden.

column3: So taxpayers should not be further pressured and you're advertising for nuclear energy? Well, then I'd like to see where a waste storage facility with a need for continuous management over the coming 200 - 1000 years can compete with the cost of a cross border electricity grid. Also, I wonder where those new reactors, that are referenced in the post, are positioned and how much they might contribute to the actual energy production of the country they're standing in? Are you talking about the swimming reactor in Russia with 35MW? Is it one of the two chinese reactors with 250MW? Or rather the reasearch reactor in India? Those are capacities that are in no way contributing in a meaningful way to our current energy landscape and claiming that they are a capable of lovering our CO2 footprint is simply a lie. What energy sources would be used to build them in the first place if renewables are somewhat categorically disregarded with what consequences (in terms of CO2)? And they are even less fuel-efficient than the classic designs, so what exactly is your point besides crude lobbyism? Renewables leave no room for baseload capacity and frankly, we don't need it. Flexibility is key and makes us more resilient in the changes to come.
column5:
taxpayers should not face additional financial pressure, yet nuclear energy is being promoted as a solution? i question how a waste storage facility, requiring ongoing management for 200‚Äì1000 years, can compete with the cost of a cross-border electricity grid. regarding the new reactors mentioned, where are these reactors located, and how much do they actually contribute to the energy production of their respective countries? 

are we discussing russia‚Äôs floating reactor with 35 mw, one of the two chinese reactors with 250 mw, or india‚Äôs research reactor? these capacities are negligible and do not meaningfully impact the current energy landscape. claiming that such reactors can significantly lower co2 emissions is misleading. 

what energy sources would be used in the construction of these reactors, especially if renewables are dismissed? what are the co2 implications of this? additionally, these new reactors are less fuel-efficient than traditional designs. what is the real purpose here, other than promoting narrow lobbying interests? 

renewables eliminate the need for baseload capacity, and baseload capacity is unnecessary. flexibility is the key to building resilience for the changes ahead.

column5:
i strongly support denmark's initiative to build the world's first true energy island. this unique project has the potential to become the most significant public-private partnership in danish history. major investors including pfa, pensiondanmark, andel, and copenhagen infrastructure partners are ready to invest capital and resources to make the energy island a reality.

the energy island will serve as a hub for 10 gw of offshore wind power while providing port and housing facilities for maintenance vessels and personnel. the island ensures optimal conditions for innovation in large-scale energy storage and power-to-x technology. when comparing costs with a traditional steel platform for 3 gw capacity, the island concept offers much more flexibility and future opportunities at a similar cost. the island's innovative construction will give denmark a first-mover advantage in creating a danish business success story, as denmark will be the first to gain experience in building such a facility.

the danish energy agency has just announced that bornholm will become denmark's third electricity trading marketplace through the establishment of a new bidding zone. when energy island bornholm begins operations and the new electricity trading connection between denmark and germany is established, this new marketplace for electricity trading will be created.

energinet's island team has conducted a thorough analysis showing there will be greater demand for transfer capacity than the cables can deliver. this creates a bottleneck in the market, which will be managed through the bornholm bidding zone. this third danish bidding zone will not significantly impact electricity prices on bornholm, as prices will largely follow those in either eastern denmark or germany. individual consumers will not notice any difference in their electricity bills.

the new bidding zone will only take effect when energy island bornholm becomes operational. the market structure is now ready, representing an important step toward realizing energy island bornholm.

rwe is proud to have won the historic thor tender in 2021, which is not only a milestone for rwe but for danish offshore wind in general. the clarification regarding the planned hydrogen pipeline between denmark and germany is a crucial factor for future energy production in denmark. this hydrogen pipeline can ensure that excess electricity from future energy production reaches where energy is needed.

the hydrogen pipeline will enable the conversion of surplus electricity into hydrogen for export to germany and other european countries. it is crucial for industry and the green transition that the danish government provides clarity on the regulation of the hydrogen pipeline, including the cost of using this infrastructure.

denmark remains an exciting market for rwe, and rwe is deeply committed to advancing the green transition. rwe looks forward to continued dialogue with the government and other authorities to ensure the best framework conditions for future offshore wind and hydrogen projects.

kraka economics calls for an immediate halt to the bornholm energy island project, which represents economically reckless behavior. the bornholm energy island was initially presented as a profitable project but is now expected to be unprofitable both in terms of socioeconomic and project economics.

the latest calculations show an expected need for subsidies of 31.5 billion danish kroner, despite the fact that other offshore wind projects can be constructed without subsidies. politicians have set a subsidy cap of 17.6 billion danish kroner, leaving a deficit of 14 billion danish kroner. despite this massive funding gap, parts of the project have already been put out to tender, and the remaining parts are expected to be tendered in several stages throughout 2024.

the ongoing tender process for an underfunded project is extremely risky, as multiple contracts will likely be entered into before determining whether the project can be realized. breaking these contracts, if necessary, would likely incur significant costs.

column3:
The Economy of Energy Island Bornholm: Remember the Vision, It Holds the Key!

Today, Energy Island Bornholm is once again in the spotlight as the economic experts recommend an updated socio-economic analysis and emphasize the importance of societal economic profitability. Suggesting that the experts have pulled the rug out from under the project is, in my view, misleading. It is important to remember that the figures they reference are the same ones that an overwhelming majority in Parliament based their latest decision on in May 2023. Despite this, I support new calculations, as the current debate is based on 2023 data, which is already outdated.

I urge that new calculations include significant factors that are currently not accounted for, such as energy security in DK2, expected EU funding, and the impact of a potential delay, for example, of two years.

The most important thing, however, is to remember and include the values embedded in the dual vision that initiated the project.

First, Bornholm is optimally positioned as a hub connecting energy markets in the Baltic Sea. Therefore, the land installations have been prepared from the outset for additional connections to both Poland and Sweden. The connection to Poland, currently under negotiation, will significantly improve the project‚Äôs economy through bottleneck revenues.

Second, Bornholm serves as a platform for learning and innovation, paving the way for other energy islands crucial to Europe‚Äôs green transition. This is of great importance to the Danish wind industry, which has the potential to become a global leader in energy islands, just as it has in onshore and offshore wind.

Both aspects should be considered when assessing the socio-economic viability of the energy island. Is it possible to account for all factors? No, it is hardly realistic, and that is why the final decision must rest with the politicians‚Äîfortunately.
column5:
the energy island bornholm project must be evaluated with a focus on its original vision, as this vision holds the key to its value. while the economic experts have recommended an updated socio-economic analysis and emphasized the importance of profitability, it is misleading to suggest they have undermined the project. the data they reference is the same that an overwhelming majority in parliament based their decision on in may 2023. nevertheless, i support new calculations since the current debate relies on outdated figures.

i urge that updated calculations include critical factors not previously considered, such as energy security in dk2, anticipated eu funding, and the potential impact of a delay of two years.

most importantly, the double vision behind the project must not be forgotten. bornholm is uniquely positioned as a hub linking energy markets in the baltic sea, with land installations already prepared for additional connections to poland and sweden. the connection to poland, currently under negotiation, could significantly enhance the project's profitability through bottleneck revenues.

furthermore, bornholm serves as a platform for learning and innovation, paving the way for other energy islands essential for europe‚Äôs green transition. this is crucial for denmark‚Äôs wind industry, which has the potential to lead globally in energy island development, as it has with onshore and offshore wind.

both of these aspects must be factored into the socio-economic assessment. while it may not be possible to quantify every factor, the final decision rightly rests with policymakers.

Government officials estimate the project will require DKK 30 billion in state subsidies.

Drop Energy Island Bornholm.

column5: the economic viability of the energy island bornholm project is simply too poor. government officials estimate the project will require dkk 30 billion in state subsidies. this should be compared to other offshore wind projects that require no subsidies and, in some cases, even generate revenue for the state. i recommend that we abandon the energy island bornholm project, quickly identify an alternative, more cost-effective location for the same offshore wind capacity and reallocate the dkk 30 billion saved to other valuable initiatives.

column3:
One Good and One Bad News

This is how Lars Aagaard's announcement about the breakdown of negotiations with the Belgians over the North Sea Energy Island and the resulting project delay must be described.

It is bad news because we need all the green electricity we can get to produce green fuels, especially for shipping. The first green ships have long been launched, and many more are on the way. Therefore, it is unfortunate that it will take a bit longer before the North Sea Energy Island becomes a reality.

However, it is also good news that the Germans appear ready to take over where the Belgians left off. Germany is already involved in Energy Island Bornholm, and I hope this means there is a better foundation for securing an agreement between Denmark and Germany.

As first movers, it is inevitable to encounter challenges and problems. What matters is not being deterred but finding new paths and opportunities when one door closes.

I, therefore, wish the government good luck in securing a deal with the Germans. We are rooting for you.
column5:
lars aagaard‚Äôs announcement about the failed negotiations with the belgians over the north sea energy island and the resulting project delay brings both good and bad news.

the bad news is that denmark urgently needs all the green electricity it can get to produce green fuels, particularly for shipping, where the first green ships are already in operation, with many more on the way. the delay in making the north sea energy island a reality is therefore disappointing.

the good news is that germany appears ready to take over where belgium left off. since germany is already involved in energy island bornholm, this increases the likelihood of successfully securing an agreement between denmark and germany.

as first movers in green energy projects, challenges and setbacks are inevitable. the key is to stay on course and explore new paths when obstacles arise.

i fully support the government in securing a deal with germany and wish them the best of luck. we are rooting for their success.

as jacob tr√∏st, i am pleased to announce that the collaboration regarding the energy islands in the baltic sea has been strengthened today with the signing of a letter of intent. gotland, √•land, and bornholm face many of the same challenges and opportunities as we move toward becoming energy islands. in just a few years, we will transition from being on the periphery to the center of a new energy reality.

during an inspiring trip to aabenraa and fredericia, bornholm had the opportunity to explore the potential and requirements of power to x (ptx/green fuels). bornholm is looking toward an exciting future with 3.2-3.8 gigawatts of green electricity generated by energy island bornholm, and the opportunities that this will create.

we heard fascinating and inspiring presentations about the extensive administrative work and planning needed in municipalities, as well as the involvement of citizens and businesses. we also visited a solar park in hjolderup, where grazing was managed by sheep under the supervision of trained dogs, a refinery in fredericia with its own employee training program, presentations on ptx from the danish energy agency, and we saw ptx facilities in operation and under construction. furthermore, valuable connections were made.

i would like to thank mayors jan riber jakobsen from aabenraa and steen wrist from fredericia, as well as all the other presenters and guides for their excellent and relevant presentations and for warmly welcoming us. special thanks to port of roenne a/s and gate21, supported by denmark‚Äôs business promotion board, for organizing the well-executed trip. üëç

today, i had the opportunity to host minister of climate, energy, and utilities lars aagaard, who was eager to hear our thoughts on the future work with energy island bornholm.

we toured the area where the onshore facility will be located and then held a meeting at the old power station in r√∏nne.

the minister was engaged and knowledgeable, and we presented the vision that energy island should serve as a catalyst for bornholm‚Äôs development, contributing to both energy and economic sustainability.

along with other group leaders, i highlighted several key requests, including compensation for neighbors and the bornholm community, consideration for nature and the environment, apprenticeships, increased transport capacity, service harbors, green vocational training, research, and business development.

we also discussed the business opportunities arising when over 3 gigawatts of green electricity are brought ashore in bornholm.

this was followed by excellent presentations from energinet, baltic energy island, port of roenne a/s, bornholms energi & forsyning, dtu - technical university of denmark, and √∏rsted, all sharing exciting visions and opportunities for bornholm.

i believe the minister left with valuable inspiration and the impression that we are approaching this project constructively.

column3:
Ready for the islands?
 
Today we announce our plans to develop 2 energy islands in the German North Sea. The islands are located +100 KM from the German shoreline, have the size of about 70 soccer fields, and will be a key enabler of the German energy transition. Key advantages:
 
‚û°Ô∏è Local & affordable green hydrogen: Produce large quantities of local green hydrogen that is powered by neighboring offshore wind farms. Producing hydrogen in Germany will make us more energy independent, significantly reduce costs of green hydrogen, and save costs on grid expansion
‚û°Ô∏è Flexibility and optionality for the German energy system: When we need electricity, we deliver the electricity from the wind farms to the consumer and when we have sufficient electricity, we produce & store green hydrogen
‚û°Ô∏è Transmission infrastructure: We can build transmission infrastructure on the island that is needed for neighboring offshore wind farms, which would lead to significant cost saving and increase efficiency
‚û°Ô∏è Health and safety: Rescuing offshore workers far out at sea is a challenge for the industry. It is our highest priority to get our technicians the help they need in time. Islands can have an emergency medical center where we can offer aid much faster and more independent from weather conditions
‚û°Ô∏è Operation and maintenance (O&M): For the service of offshore wind farms far out at sea, the offshore industry currently plans to use so called Service Operation Vessels (SOVs), where technicians live on a ship for weeks. Having an island next to offshore wind farms will allow the service teams to live and work in a more convenient and safe work environment
‚û°Ô∏è Protect & defend our critical infrastructure: Parts of our critical infrastructure are at sea and they are vulnerable, as we have seen last year. Islands can enable us to better monitor and if necessary defend us
‚û°Ô∏è Environmental benefits: natural islands far out at sea are teeming with life above and below the water - the same will happen with our artificial energy islands. We will design them in an eco-friendly way to maximize benefits for nature
‚û°Ô∏è Jobs jobs jobs: we expect to create +10.000 jobs, many of them in Germany. Especially the coastal communities will benefit, yet also other regions will see job growth along the supply chain.
 
I'm very much looking forward to developing the islands with our great team at Copenhagen Offshore Partners and together with our strategic partner Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners.
column5:
the development of energy islands in the german north sea is a transformative project that i fully support. these islands, located over 100 kilometers from the german shoreline and spanning an area the size of approximately 70 soccer fields, will play a critical role in advancing germany's energy transition. 

the energy islands will enable the local production of green hydrogen powered by nearby offshore wind farms, reducing dependency on foreign energy, cutting green hydrogen costs, and minimizing the need for extensive grid expansion. they will provide flexibility by delivering electricity when needed and producing and storing green hydrogen during periods of surplus electricity.

the islands will also serve as hubs for efficient transmission infrastructure for offshore wind farms, resulting in significant cost savings and increased operational efficiency. additionally, the islands will address health and safety challenges by hosting emergency medical centers, ensuring offshore workers receive timely assistance regardless of weather conditions.

for operation and maintenance of offshore wind farms, the islands will eliminate the need for technicians to live on service operation vessels (sovs) for weeks, offering a safer and more comfortable work environment. they will also enhance the protection of critical infrastructure at sea, providing better monitoring and defense capabilities.

the islands will be designed to support biodiversity, creating eco-friendly environments that benefit marine and terrestrial life. moreover, the project is expected to generate over 10,000 jobs, benefiting coastal communities and other regions across the supply chain.

i am excited to lead this initiative with copenhagen offshore partners and copenhagen infrastructure partners, confident that it will bring economic, environmental, and strategic benefits to germany.

Bis 2040 sollen es dann sogar schon 40 GW sein. column5: the german government‚Äôs konjunkturpaket, passed in june, has laid a solid foundation for expanding wind energy. by 2030, offshore wind turbines are expected to achieve 20 gigawatts instead of the previously planned 15 gigawatts, with a target of 40 gigawatts by 2040. this increase was urgently needed because the previous cap would likely have halted the construction of additional offshore wind energy projects in the coming years. in my opinion, these new ambitions will revitalize the market. while offshore wind energy has been dominated by large german and danish energy companies, the new targets will attract global players like shell, equinor, and total, creating positive effects for the market and, most importantly, advancing germany‚Äôs energy transition.

column3:
A Call for Thoughtful Innovation

Our oceans are already under immense pressure from pollution and human activity. Adding large-scale, hazardous structures that compromise both human safety and marine ecosystems is not the solution. Offshore wind turbines are not as harmless as they are portrayed. Instead, we must explore safer, more sustainable alternatives that do not endanger lives or the environment.

The promise of clean energy should not come at the expense of safety and ecological balance. By prioritizing thoughtful innovation and robust risk assessments, we can work towards energy solutions that truly benefit humanity and the planet.

column3:
Even if electricity demand in Europe were to rise significantly starting tomorrow, there would still be a major problem: the power grid is severely underdimensioned, especially in Germany. In fact, it is already a problem today to distribute electricity effectively in our large neighboring country, and a solution to this issue is still a long way off. However, one way to partially address the problem would be to connect Danish wind farms directly to the German power grid well south of the border. This was mentioned by several sources I spoke with.

Dennis Jul Pedersen, the director of the Port of Esbjerg and someone with extensive knowledge of the offshore wind industry, brought this up as the very first point when I called him: interconnectors‚Äîhuge, thick electrical cables leading directly to the major cities in Germany. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what is needed because then you can sell your electricity on the market,‚Äù he said.
column5: the european power grid, particularly in germany, is significantly underdimensioned, creating challenges in effectively distributing electricity. addressing this issue will take considerable time. one solution to mitigate this problem is to connect danish wind farms directly to the german power grid further south of the border. as director of the port of esbjerg with extensive knowledge of the offshore wind industry, i emphasize the importance of interconnectors‚Äîlarge, thick electrical cables directly linking danish wind farms to major german cities. these interconnectors are essential to enable the sale of electricity on the market.
column13: Electricity markets and bidding zones

column3: Several sources also highlight the Danish Parliament's requirement for state co-ownership of wind farms. The question arises: to what extent would the state interfere in the business? One of those advocating for dropping the requirement in the future is Finn Lauritzen, chief economist at the Business Think Tank, who has conducted several analyses of the offshore wind market in recent years. "The requirement for state co-ownership was introduced two or three years ago when people still believed there was gold on the seabed, and even then, we warned against it," he says. State co-ownership, as you might have guessed, creates uncertainty.
column5: the requirement for state co-ownership of wind farms, introduced by the danish parliament, has raised concerns about the extent of state interference in business operations. i believe this requirement should be eliminated in the future. it was implemented two to three years ago under the assumption that there was significant untapped value in offshore wind projects, but even at that time, i warned against it. state co-ownership introduces uncertainty into the market, which can hinder the development and success of offshore wind projects.
column13: Bureaucracy and regulation

column3: One final‚Äîand slightly more controversial‚Äîoption to reduce some of the financial risks for offshore wind developers is simply to guarantee them a minimum price for electricity. This can be achieved through so-called Contracts for Difference, where the state guarantees a minimum price for electricity on one hand but receives payment if the electricity ends up being sold for more than the agreed minimum price. According to Hans Henrik Lindboe from Ea Energy Analysis, this is probably the only measure that can definitively ensure the success of the next Danish offshore wind tender. "There are arguments both for and against it, but our assessment is that if you want to be absolutely certain that there will be bidders, then this is the way to go," he says.
column5: one potentially controversial but effective solution to reduce financial risks for offshore wind developers is to guarantee a minimum price for electricity through contracts for difference. with these contracts, the state promises to pay a minimum price for electricity but also receives payments if the electricity sells for more than the agreed minimum price. based on my assessment, this is likely the only measure that can ensure the success of the next danish offshore wind tender. while there are arguments both for and against this approach, if the goal is to guarantee that there will be bidders, this is the strategy that must be pursued

"Energi√∏ Bornholm
Teksten nedenfor er indledningen til min note om Energi√∏ Bornholm. Man kan ikke l√¶ngere vedh√¶fte en fil eller et link til poster p√• Linkedin, men jeg sender gerne hele noten til interesserede.

Energi√∏ Bornholm er udset til at bane vejen for, at Danmark kan bevare sin f√∏rende position som gr√∏nt pionerland.
Det √òkonomiske R√•d har advaret om projektets d√•rlige samfunds√∏konomi. Et indl√¶g i Jyllands-Posten den 25. december 2024 fremh√¶ver de fordele, som ikke indg√•r i de √∏konomiske analyser, herunder dansk teknologisk f√∏rerposition, vejen til nye internationale elforbindelser, forsyningssikkerhed og jobskabelse p√• Bornholm.
Det er luftige og velkendte argumenter. N√•r man pr√∏ver at skabe sig en mere konkret forst√•else af projektet, viser det sig at v√¶re syltet ind i mange ord men kun f√• brugbare oplysninger. Det g√¶lder is√¶r projektets tekniske indretning.
Mine konklusioner om Energi√∏ Bornholm
- Det er et alvorligt demokratisk problem, at dele af dokumentationen for en s√• stor samfundsinvestering er m√∏rklagt.
- Der findes s√• godt som ingen offentligt tilg√¶ngelig information om de valgte tekniske l√∏sninger. Det afsk√¶rer teknisk interesserede fra at vurdere projektets tekniske risici.
- Siden Energinets ‚ÄùBusiness case‚Äù fra 2022 er forventningen til projektets samfunds√∏konomi blevet kraftigt forringet. Derfor skal der tages stilling til, om projektet skal √¶ndres eller opgives.
- Valget af en energi√∏ frem for en platformsl√∏sning medf√∏rer koncentration af store energioms√¶tninger i f√• punkter og dermed √∏get s√•rbarhed af elforsyningen i Danmark og i resten af Europa. I lyset af √∏gede internationale sp√¶ndinger b√∏r dette valg revurderes.
- Den tekniske sammenkobling p√• energi√∏en betegnes i Energinets risikovurdering som ‚Äùumoden‚Äù. Det er mildt udtrykt, for sammenkoblingen er udfordrende, og indtil videre kun fors√∏gt fors√∏gt i fuld skala ganske f√• steder i verden.
- Ingen danske virksomheder udvikler eller producerer HVDC-udstyr, s√• det tjener ingen dansk interesse at satse p√• upr√∏vede l√∏sninger. Multiterminal offshore HVDC-l√∏sninger b√∏r ikke i nogen form indg√• i projektet, f√∏r de n√∏dvendige nye teknologier er fuldt afpr√∏vet andre steder.
- Analyser af alternative l√∏sninger er fors√∏mt. P√• grund af d√•rlig √∏konomi og teknologisk usikkerhed b√∏r projektet stiles i bero, indtil alle relevante l√∏sninger er ordentligt unders√∏gt og vurderet."
column5:
energi√∏ bornholm is intended to help denmark maintain its leading position as a green pioneer nation. however, the economic council has warned of the project‚Äôs poor societal economics. an article in jyllands-posten on december 25, 2024, highlights the advantages not included in the economic analyses, such as denmark‚Äôs technological leadership, new international power connections, energy security, and job creation on bornholm. these are familiar, yet vague arguments. when attempting to gain a clearer understanding of the project, it becomes evident that it is surrounded by much talk but few useful details, particularly concerning its technical setup.

my conclusions regarding energi√∏ bornholm are as follows:
- it is a serious democratic issue that parts of the documentation for such a large public investment are kept secret.
- there is almost no publicly available information about the chosen technical solutions, which prevents those with technical interest from evaluating the project's risks.
- since energinet‚Äôs 2022 ""business case,"" the expectation for the project‚Äôs societal economics has significantly worsened. therefore, we must decide whether the project should be altered or abandoned.
- the decision to choose an energy island over a platform solution results in the concentration of significant energy transactions at a few points, thus increasing the vulnerability of denmark‚Äôs electricity supply and europe‚Äôs overall grid. in light of rising international tensions, this decision should be reconsidered.
- the technical connection on the energy island is described in energinet‚Äôs risk assessment as ""immature."" this is a mild expression, as the connection is challenging and has only been attempted on a large scale in a few locations worldwide.
- no danish companies develop or produce hvdc equipment, so there is no national benefit in betting on untested solutions. multi-terminal offshore hvdc solutions should not be included in the project in any form until these new technologies have been thoroughly tested elsewhere.
- analyses of alternative solutions have been neglected. due to poor economics and technological uncertainty, the project should be put on hold until all relevant solutions have been properly investigated and evaluated.

Energy islands: The hottest topic in offshore wind
But here's what most don't realise:
It's not just about power generation. 
It's about smart distribution
Picture this: A central hub in the middle of the sea. Collecting power from surrounding wind farms. Then sending it to where it's needed most.
No more individual cables to shore. 
Just one BIG connection.
Imagine the North Sea covered in cables.
Like spaghetti strewn across the seabed
‚Üí That's what we're facing WITHOUT energy islands.
Efficient? You bet.

Jeg har brugt ugen i Davos, hvor World Economic Forums √•rsm√∏de traditionen tro danner rammen om inspirerende samtaler om muligheder og udfordringer i den globale √∏konomi.

Behovet for private investeringer i den gr√∏nne omstilling var et af de store tilbagevende emner, og selv om der er sket meget med udbredelsen af sol- og vindenergi de seneste 10 √•r, s√• er der brug for markante nye skridt for at komme p√• sporet af m√•ls√¶tningerne om CO2-reduktioner og meget mere vedvarende energi.
 
Derfor er jeg glad og stolt over, at vi i dag kan fort√¶lle, at PensionDanmark er blandt investorerne i CEI ‚Äì Copenhagen Energy Islands. Et nyt selskab dedikeret til udvikling af energi√∏er, som rummer et globalt, kommercielt potentiale for den kommende fase i den gr√∏nne omstilling, og som derfor kan give en attraktiv forrentning af vores medlemmers pensionsopsparinger. 
 
Der er store planer for udbygning af havvind p√• tv√¶rs af verden, og dermed udsigt til en massiv produktion af gr√∏n str√∏m. Str√∏m, der bl.a. skal bruges i en storskalaproduktion af gr√∏n brint, der som flydende br√¶ndstof kan blive n√∏glen til en gr√∏n omstilling af skibstransport, flytrafik, landbrug og tung industri. 
 
Energi√∏er har potentiale til at blive de naturlige knudepunkter i den globale infrastruktur for flydende gr√∏n brint, og CEI har en pipeline p√• ti potentielle projekter p√• tv√¶rs af Nords√∏en, √òsters√∏en og Syd√∏stasien.
 
Investorkredsen t√¶ller danske og internationale kapaciteter som @PFA, @Andel og @SEB - og i spidsen for det hele st√•r @CIP, der om nogen har vist, hvordan mod og vilje til forandring kan give en f√∏rerposition i den gr√∏nne omstilling.
 
Ambitionerne er store, og det samme er potentialet for s√•vel afkast til medlemmerne som bidrag til den gr√∏nne omstilling. 
 
S√• det er med god grund, at jeg gl√¶der mig til at f√∏lge udviklingen i CEI.
column5:
i spent the week in davos at the world economic forum‚Äôs annual meeting, where discussions centered on challenges and opportunities in the global economy. a key recurring theme was the need for private investment in the green transition. while progress has been made in solar and wind energy over the past decade, substantial new steps are necessary to meet co2 reduction targets and expand renewable energy.  

i am proud to announce that pensiondanmark is among the investors in copenhagen energy islands (cei), a new company dedicated to developing energy islands with global and commercial potential for advancing the green transition. this investment is expected to provide attractive returns for pensiondanmark members.  

the global offshore wind sector has significant expansion plans, which will lead to large-scale production of green electricity. this electricity will support the large-scale production of green hydrogen, which has the potential to revolutionize industries such as shipping, aviation, agriculture, and heavy industry by providing sustainable liquid fuel.  

energy islands are poised to become key hubs in the global infrastructure for green hydrogen. cei is actively developing a pipeline of ten potential energy island projects across the north sea, baltic sea, and southeast asia.  

the group of investors includes danish and international entities such as pfa, andel, and seb, with copenhagen infrastructure partners (cip) leading the initiative. cip has demonstrated exceptional leadership in driving the green transition through bold action and innovation.  

the ambitions for cei are immense, both in terms of delivering strong financial returns for members and contributing meaningfully to the global green transition. i am excited to follow cei‚Äôs progress.
